< name>
PDXTraveler<//name>
<resp>None<//resp><user_id>None</user_id>< Text>
While the exterior and public spaces of the Palace Hotel continue to convey a sense of glamour and quality the guest room experience is anything but. On a recent stay our premium room was drastically under furnished (two small chairs in a vast room which could easily have accommodated a sofa or at the minimum an end of bed divan) and sorely lacking in any sort of usable storage - all that was provided were two old suitcases masquerading as lockers, one of which had a broken close so constantly slammed shut on your hands. 

The bathroom while small was modern and well equipped but we were astonished at the lack of any mini bar or other similar facilities despite the provision of a fridge.

The crowning touch of the room however was the complete lack of any sort of sound proofing against the corridor or adjacent (locked door) room. With a crying infant next door you will not be getting any sleep. If you do manage to fall asleep however the beds are at least comfortable.

Unfortunately I cannot imagine ever wanting to stay in this hotel again unless they really invest in bringing the rooms up to date</Text>

<user>None<//user>< text>
Hotel was immaculate and well worth the group rate price associated with a large convention. Standard queen double was roomy with little to no noise penetration from the hall or neighbors. Bed area had insufficient outlets and decorated with an overabundance of huge pillows - far too big for sleeping. Why not provide a variety, so that guests can choose the ones most well suited for their physiques? No simple breakfast option was available and this fine hotel had no dinner options. On the other hand, the Pied Piper Bar & Grill food and service was excellent.</text>

< Review>
Beautiful hotel in a great location. The staff was over the top helpful during my 7 day stay. I They even sent a seamstress to my room within minutes after I saw I needed my pants hemmed!
The piano player in The Garden Court every evening was amazing!
They things they do need to step up on is the internet speed and connection, not sure why they still charge in 2014. Also, no in-room coffee, again, it's 2014 so it should be a given. It takes 10-15 minutes to walk down to the lobby to get coffee at in the mornings, didn't have the time to spare. At least I had a mini fridge I could keep my two free bottles of water every day. Overall it was a great place to stay.<//Review>

<Review>Exceptional staff, communication and gorgeous hotel. I had e-mailed the Hotel Manager, Mr. Sneen. He immediately e-mailed me that night, at midnight! What prompt service! I was informing him that my husband and our friends were heading to SF for a nice getaway weekend to celebrate a birthday and retirement. I had asked for a suite and adjoining room. Mr. Sneen and his staff went above and beyond to accommodate our request. From start the finish, the stay was amazing. The staff was extremely helpful and attentive. The room, lobby and overall hotel were GORGEOUS. I love the historic beauty of the hotel, it truly is San Francisco glamour at its best. The gold plated d√©cor, stairways, beautiful stain glass, marble, lighting, etc immediately transports you back to the gilded age. We weren‚Äôt able to check in early, but the room and welcome amenities were well worth the wait. We were surprised twice with delectable desserts and a bottle of wine. The rooms were beautiful and spacious. With my Platinum benefit, we opted for breakfast. We had a lovely breakfast in the atrium was breathtaking. The food was very good and the staff were helpful. We could not have had a better weekend and we look forward to staying again this upcoming baseball season! The staff should be commended for their excellent work.</Review>< Pics>

<text>The hotel is great! The lobby looks like a real palace and it is very fancy. The staff are very friendly.

While he was cleaning up next to us, he even hit my head with his elbow. How ever, we didn't hear any words apologizing for it.

< text>
This hotel is more focused on operational efficiency and bottom line and has lost sight of the customer. Upon check in, there was a rate that was $50 less expensive then one I reserved of which all other SPG hotels accommodate, this one didn't. I had to stand in line again on the second day because they only gave me one Platinum breakfast voucher and you have to have one for each day at this hotel. One day returning to hotel, my key didn't work and I had to go to the front desk and stand in line two times to get it working again. Hair on floor in rest room and tub upon first day of arrival, blinds not fully shut for turn down service, piles of trash and recycling left in halls for extended periods of time. Rooms, food, hotel itself is good but service was what you would expect at a Sheraton or 4 points.< /text>

<Review>The room we booked was an interior room, which was quiet but no view. Since we live in the bay area and were just in San Fran for the night, we didn't need much. The room was large and very nicely put together. Love the updated bathroom and decor - very tasteful and still paying homage to the heritage. And bath salts in the bathroom amenities is an excellent touch! Room service was astronomically expensive (we have stayed in 5 star hotels that didn't charge this much). Also, we utilized the hotel parking, called ahead to have them pull the car around, checked out and was out front within 15 min. However, we stood out front for another 35 minutes waiting for our car (we were asked what number we had twice, but nothing came of it) until I got restless and started walking around on the sidewalk, where I found our car parked a little ways down the street. It had been there for ages! And then we got no luggage assistance or apology. Sloppy. They were busy, but...
Overall, the hotel is beautiful and the location is awesome. Service from front desk was good. But lots of little things were not great.</Review><Pics>None< /Pics>< response>

<text>Probably the finest hotel in San Francisco.  The lobby and bar are rich and opulent, rooms are cleaner and newer than the hotel St. Francis.   There is an air of elitism about the place.  Near major businesses at New Montgomery and Market.<//text>< Pictures>

<review>I was excited for my stay at the Palace hotel over the Christmas holidays, including requesting the Santa High Tea for my family. At check-in, the Front Desk agent was very friendly and accommodating, giving a brief overview of the amenities and options at the hotel, including the fitness center and pool which were on the same floor as my room. The lobby was very festive with the Gingerbread house contest and the Christmas decorations, including the huge tree!

The room itself reflects the old decor of the Grand Dame hotels. The fitness center down the hall was well equipped with a nice pool and sauna which came in handy after a long flight. The attendant could not have been more helpful and cheery.

The only major disappointment was at the Tea with Santa where the Hostess forced our table to be reseated behind the Christmas tree as she had given our table to another set of guests whilst we were in line to take a photo with Santa. She did not offer to reseat the second party and return us to the original table. Overall the tea service was average, and certainly not as good as previous Afternoon Tea services at the Palace. Management has assured that this will be addressed.

While housecleaning was good, my unit could have used a check behind the sofa. When I went to retrieve a lens cap that slipped under, I noticed a few bits of garbage behind there.

The staff was very attentive and friendly. The valets and front door staff were exceptionally helpful. Aside from the Hostess, the only other people who were the exception to the stellar staff were the two individuals at the front desk when I checked out. Neither bothered to look up when I was checking out!

Over the years, I have had a chance to stay at some of the nicest hotels in the world, including many Starwood properties. I would stay at the Palace again, but I would not rate this a good, but not, Luxury stay.<//review>< Gmap_id>

<review>Stayed in 2014.

Made the mistake of booking through an external site. Didn't tell us that debit wasn't accepted and we would have to lay down a $200 cash deposit which we had to talk down to $100 as we didn't have the money on hand. The staff wasn't very kind to us after this, treating us with contempt.

The person checking us in even went so far as to imply that my girlfriend was my mom and that we were going to go up to the hotel room to do...things.

We ended up calling Starwood after that little stunt and they gave us half off our next room, which is fine I guess, but still. The vibe I got off this hotel is that if you even look like you're NOT rich, you'll be treated badly. The girlfriend and I saved like hell for this trip for Christmas and we got treated horribly for all that effort.

In stark contrast to the Hotel Carlton which we stayed at recently, they treated us extremely well.

That said, the Palace is a nice looking hotel and it may well have changed since that incident, but I would proceed with caution.</review><userid>103734735635787465490< /userid>< Resp>

< Review>
An Excellent Hotel to stay for location, comfort and service. 
The down side is the light fixtures: desk lamp's light level is too low and shining right into your eyes when you try to work on your paper works. So is the lower set of light on the mirror in the washroom, the reading light switch above the bed are too high for small built guests, who has to stand up on bed to turn it off after reading in bed.
Bathroom tissues location is also terrible, you have to turn more than 45 degrees to get your tissues, its hard for fat people to reach.

There are also no drawer chest to spread out your clothing when you stay for a few days, your under garments have to go back to your luggage everyday.

Staff are very very friendly and helpful, great place to spend your vacation or overnight stay.</Review>

< name>
TimOC11< /name>
<date>1404691200000<//date><rate>None<//rate>< Text>
Overall stay was positive as the staff were helpful and professional. Hotel is nice and rooms were clean. Hotel reservations folks were great as they helped accomodate us with a bigger room and rollaways which was very helpful. This was the positive part.

The area for improvement would be:
1) Food for room service - food was mediocre but to top it off both my daughter and myself found oursleves with some stomach issues (and we both had the burger)
2) TV - was not working correctly on HD channels. Engineering came and fixed it which was a simple reset that should have occurred when they switched software. I guess I would have expected that all TVs were reset.
3) Front desk could be staffed with additional people as we had to wait each time we were there - along with no SPG preferred lane.
4) No turn down one night - not even a knock to see if it was wanted.

In the end, the staff made the stay positive but for a luxury collection the areas where we had issues should not have occurred.< /Text>

<user_id>None<//user_id>< text>
I stayed here last year and had a subpar experience (mostly related to billing and AMEX Plat perks), however, a manager convinced me to try again. I'm glad I did. The two days spent here showed me that the staff and facility are top notch and do actually care to provide wonderful service.

While my room had an issue with the air conditioner, I set it at 65, yet it refused to budge from 72, it still was a reasonable temp to sleep and do a little catch up work with. 

One highlight, the concierge Chinatsu. Chinatsu was able to secure me a reservation for myself and a client at a restaurant that was booked through mid-July...45 days out. I don't know how it was managed, but thank you! I tried to stop by the desk twice and was unable to connect and show my gratitude in person...but thank you very much Chinatsu, you are certainly a gem and a wonderful asset for this hotel!

The conference portion seemed a little subpar...poor audio/video at a couple of the sessions, and lack of food (which may have been the hosting org fault), put a little mark on the experience, but overall, I think the place was excellent and I'll certainly plan future stays here.</text>

<date>1358294400000<//date>< Text>
OVERALL IMPRESSION: Certainly a Grande Dame amongst American hotels and honorably maintained.

SPG RECOGNITION: Upgrade to a Suite. No in-room amenity. Platinum Breakfast is the full buffet - which is spectacular - in the glorious Garden Court.

THE ROOM: Beautiful and traditional top-floor corner suite with all modern amenities but a classic ‚ÄúGrand Hotel‚Äù feel. I loved the large arched and curved corner window looking down on the city.

LOCATION: At the very heart of San Francisco just a few yards from Union Square, SoMA and the Theatre District.

EXCEEDED EXPECTATIONS: Surprisingly, the hotel‚Äôs highly-touted Japanese restaurant has been closed. This was something of a disappointment because - as it was still appearing on the SPG Restaurants and Bars site a- we had planned to dine there after a visit to the theater. The other restaurant would be closed by the time we got back but the manager, Brian, went out of his way to arrange for us to dine on the restaurant menu in the adjacent bar upon our return. And the meal was just right.

DID NOT MEET EXPECTATIONS: Attention to detail is a make-or-break issue at this uppermost echelon of hostelry and, therefore, where in a lesser property oversights can be easily forgiven, I find it disturbing that here there didn‚Äôt seem to be too much effort to get it right. For example, having been advised of my very reasonable arrival time of 15h30, one would think there would have been a greater push to have the room ready. When it was not, the reception clerk simply suggested we ‚Äúgo for a walk‚Äù with no gesture of compensation or apology. Although the hotel received a list of special requests, none of them were honored. When I called Guest services for the two Martini glasses which should have been there already, I waited 20 minutes and was brought two tumblers. When I questioned the attendant who brought them, he said the hotel had no Martini glasses! Highly unlikely when it is the home of the Pied Piper Bar - famous for its Martinis</Text>

<gmapID>0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb< /gmapID><Text>I have stayed at The Palace several times, and it is my favorite hotel in the San Francisco area. You can feel the 140 year history of the property throughout the corridors, rooms and spaces of the hotel. Nowhere is that history more prevalent than in the restored Garden Court restaurant - the area of the original porte cochere which was partially destroyed in the 1906 earthquake.

The guest rooms are elegantly, richly, and classically furnished.

Sunday brunch at the Garden Court is the finest around, and well worth the hefty price tag. Same goes for the High Tea on Saturday afternoon.

And the high speed internet works very well, and the other facilities are top rate as well, so this hotel is equally suited for leisure and business travelers to SF.<//Text></record>

< userid>

<Pics>None</Pics><rate>None<//rate><Date>1342569600000< /Date><Text>The Palace is a wonderful hotel located near Downtown SF. The hotel itself is very elegant and the Garden Court is the most spectacular room to eat breakfast in of any hotel I have been to.

The hotel staff is what made this stay great. Arriving earlier than the rest of my family, I was working at the desk in my room when a woman from housekeeping named May came in. After a brief conversation she left and returned with huge number of towels as there were 5 of us staying in the suite. Since I was working, she also joked about going outside to get me a sandwich so I wouldn't have to work on an empty stomach. Such a nice person.

The hotel concierge was also exceptional, helping us to plan day trips and make reservations all on last minute notice.

The rooms themselves are very nice, but dated, however there is a lot of charm in these rooms. I will say they ran a little on the small side. We had a suite and it very cramped. 2 double beds in a suite is not on par with a lot of other SPG properties I have been to. Nonetheless, the beds were comfortable.

The hotel is centrally located and is an easy walk to the Ferry Building. If you have the chance, the hotel got us a reservation at the Slanted Door at the Ferry Building. It is one of the best meals I have ever mad. Thai food.

Over all a wonderful stay and probably the best staff of any SPG hotel I have been to. Will definitely come back on my next trip to SF.</Text></record>

< Text>
Love, love, love the rooms with the high ceilings. It has an old San Francisco charm. Everything about this hotel was elegant. We had a room facing the back, we even loved the view. Pool in the atrium was beautiful. I WILL stay here again. Location was perfect! A hop, skip, jump from everthing. We walked everywhere. We went to dinner at embarcadero, lunch in union square, ice skating at SOMA. Staff was wonderful & every employee we came into contact with greeted us from the moment we entered the hotel, to the lobby, to the gym, the pool, even leaving the hotel. I've never stayed at a hotel in which we were greeted by every employee. It was very welcoming and special.</Text>

< Text>
The rooms were clean and really very nice. I have never met more friendly staff at a hotel.  The food is insanely good (I can't recommend the crab benedict enough). Although they are very conveniently located, there isn't a whole lot to do within the hotel unless you like to eat and regularly bathe in money. Seriously, this is the only downside but it's a big one. Everything is very, very expensive. Parking alone is $75 a day, and for what I paid per night for a room, I kind of expected gold-incrusted pillow chocolates or, like, my own harem. Bottom line: I very much enjoyed my stay here and for the exorbitant amount of money I paid for, frankly, just a nice hotel, I wouldn't go back.<//Text>

<user_name>AwakeLate< /user_name>< time>
1371945600000<//time>
<Rating>None<//Rating>< review>
I have been a long time guest at the Palace in SF and each time I stay I have almost the same experience. The guest rooms are beautiful, the pool area and gym are absolutely gorgeous and the staff is some of the most friendly and accommodating at any property in the world. Despite this, I continue to be shocked each time I stay by the amount of noise generated by the other guests. The walls are so thin that, on our last visit, we could hear the gentleman next door snoring. Any noise in the hallways comes directly into the rooms - including the doors opening and closing every time any guest comes or goes, the cleaning staff carts and peoples' voices. This makes it very difficult to get a good nights sleep. We had to move rooms twice on our last visit, once at 12:30 in the morning, just to find a place with less noise. Each time we moved we encountered the same issue and eventually gave up. The front desk staff was incredibly helpful and kind, they even set us up with free breakfast, champagne and strawberries for the hassle, which was greatly appreciated. However, for the amount we paid per night the amount of sleep we actually got was minimal and the experience was very disappointing. I hope they can work something out because it would be a shame to stop visiting.< /review>

idmdude</username>
< review>
I have been a Marriott Platinum member for nearly 10 years now and was extremely excited about SPG becoming part of the Marriott family. This was my first stay at an SPG property and was very much looking forward to it. The hotel was beautiful, the room was very nice, and the overall amenities were very good. It is funny, however, how one event can ruin an otherwise pleasant stay. 

I was offered a late checkout of 4:00pm when booking my room which I gladly accepted as my company had booked a conference at the hotel and my meetings were over at 12:00 on the final day. I confirmed my late checkout when checking into the hotel. Upon returning to my room on the final day, however, I found that I was already locked out and had to call security. I wanted to take advantage of rest until my redeye back to the East coast, but was disturbed by consistent knocking on my door at 2:30 by the hotel staff (even though the privacy sign was on the door). I opened to find a surprised employee who asked me if I had "just checked in". I informed her that I had a late checkout and she seemed surprised. 

Upon checking out I relayed my story to the person at the desk who said that my keys must have just stopped working (I said "both of them"). This was clearly a situation of my late checkout not being recognized and/or relayed to the hotel staff and rather than take responsibility for the error, the desk agent simply said that she would speak with the staff - almost as if it were a non issue. That was it. 

If that is the type of accountability and service that is indicative of SPG - especially with such an upscale hotel such as the Palace - then maybe my excitement was a bit premature.</review>

0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb</GmapID>

<rating>None<//rating>< text>
Requested connecting room for my family of 5. when checking in, they said they have arranged our 2 rooms to be next to each other, but not connected. Then, the front desk lady upsold me to upgrade to a suite for $300 more per night as she said the 2 rooms will then be connected. Given we have kids, I said that's fine, and I'll pay for the upgrade. We checked in and went to the rooms... they were NOT connected. when I went downstairs to discuss, there was a huge line which I had to wait again, especially the lady who checked me in wasn't at the counter anymore. I waited 20 minutes to get to my turn, and had to explain everything... then they said my original rooms that were next to each others were taken. & they were wrong about the suite would be connecting... the prior front desk lady lied. & there was NO apology. Just said oh, that was a mistake to upsell you. oh, your original rooms are gone... oh, let me try to help you now.... after 45 minutes wasted, we are back to some lower level rooms.. lame. terrible place... terrible service... the bathtub drain doesn't drain well.... standing water after shower... clearly, old and plumbing not working well. there is a smell from the sink too. might be historical, but cannot see enjoying the stay, especially the service is SO BAD!!!!!<//text>

<user_id>None</user_id><date>1446249600000</date><gmap_id>0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb</gmap_id><Text>The Palace Hotel used to be my favorite hotel in the world. <Text>This is a very nice hotel that in general provided a very nice venue for a conference I was attending, however there were a few drawbacks. First was that the staff member who checked me in was somewhat curt and rude, even though all the other people I encountered were nice, this didn't set a very good tone (was especially unwelcome after a long day of travel). Second is that the internet situation is absolutely horrendous here. Internet is indispensable to every day life now and any modern hotel provides relatively easy access to it. Except the Palace. There is wifi but it's only free in the lobby. And that's OK, I'm fine paying for wifi, but even after you pay the exorbitant rate ($8/hr) what do you get? EXTREMELY SLOW CONNECTIONS. So slow that you can barely refresh your mail. Try doing work on this connection. Further, buying the internet doesn't get you access on multiple devices (you would have to pay for your laptop and iphone separately) and the webpage that you have to use to purchase wifi time doesn't even work on mobile phone browsers.

Business travelers BEWARE this will impact your productivity.</Text>< user>

< review>
Stayed here in March 2013 for a conference. It's centrally located in the city with easy access to transportation. The rooms were clean and it was definitely one of the most quiet hotels I have ever stayed in. The staff was very accomodating. I thought the conference facilities were good. The hotel overall though was a little boring. It's an older hotel and decorated as such. There's no gift shop so if you forgot to pack anything you have to go outside the hotel. My room didn't have a view - looked into the windows of the other part of the hotel. If I was in San Francisco for pleasure rather than business I would choose another, more modern hotel.</review>

<user_name>JY2017<//user_name><date>1511740800000< /date><rate>None<//rate>< Text>
My wife and I both travel more than half the year and stay in hotels 75 plus nights or more annually and we stayed here for three nights. I'm also a loyal SPG member when possible and have even stayed in this hotel in the past but I can't recommend because the service in the atrium restaurant area is atrocious. The hotel itself is beautiful and the rooms are fine and even the Pied Piper bar area has nice service, it's just the restaurant. I had heard this from friends about the place but here's specifically what happened to us. We came at 140pm and had my parents come to meet us for lunch. I politely asked the barman who was behind the bar alone with no patrons in which area to sit so we get service for lunch or tea. He didn't even look up and said "lunch is over at 2" So I said, "ok, what about tea?" He said that starts at 2pm. So I said OK, so if we wait until 2pm we'll get service for tea/lunch/snacks? Still not looking up he just said "yeah". Already a sign we should've just left and gone somewhere else. So we sat down and waited at a dirty table with dirty glasses on it. My parents joined at 2pm and we all sat talking and waiting. At 2:20 no one had yet come to our table (or any others that were now also sitting) so I got up and walked over to the bartender again and asked where the servers were. He said "I think they are getting ready" I said,"I thought the service here started at 2?" and he said, "yes, but I think they are still getting ready". So about 10 more minutes go by and finally a server comes and takes our order. We get our drinks and 2 out of 3 come out wrong. We only get one of the 2 dishes we order and not delivered by the server so no one to discuss with. Then at 3:15 the server finally comes back and she tells us she can order it now for us because when we initially ordered we asked if the dish could be made mild which she explained that was why she hadn't ordered if for us yet, because she had to check with the kitchen, which she did but just never came and told us. I spoke to the manager several times throughout and his excuse to me was "I"m sorry, you caught us when we were changing shifts" I said, "are you open at 2pm or not?" as I would expect ANY NICE HOTEL to be staffed accordingly to WHEN THEY ARE OPEN. At this point the entire atrium area was full of other patrons and all around us we heard the same thing, same complaints, customers leaving and saying "we give up", etc.. so it was the whole place and not just us. We canceled the second dish and didn't order anything else as we didn't have time so they ruined a family reunion and then still only validated my parents parking so we had to pay $30 for their parking for this terrible experience. Again, I would stay there just because the rooms and hotel itself are nice and nice location, I just wouldn't spend a dime or another minute of my time in the restaurant. Note to the hotel - figure out your food and beverage service if you want to be considered a premium hotel. Sad waste of a great place and historic hotel.</Text>

<gmapID>0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb<//gmapID><user_id>None</user_id>< text>
The Palace Hotel is old and, at least in my room, it showed. The ironing board wouldn't stand up on it's own, so I had to lean it against a wall to use it. There was a badly cracked tile in the bathroom. There was hook on the wall inside the closet that was pulled out and hanging on by a thread. When I left my room the first morning I left a $10.00 tip for the maid, which is my custom. When I returned to the room later I was dismayed to find that the toilet paper roll had not been replaced, nor was there a backup roll anywhere to be found. When I first arrived at the hotel the toilet paper roll was already half gone, so what was left on the second day was less than a quarter of a roll. By the time I was ready to leave my room the next morning the toilet paper was completely gone and I was using Kleenex. Needless to say, I did not leave a tip the second day.<//text>

<rating>None<//rating><text>Hotel is beautiful and my wife and I checked it out years ago as a wedding venue. We finally decided to stay here on a quick getaway and here is my list of things you should know when booking
(1) Rooms are Small, but acceptable if you get a good price
(2) No drawers in the room so if you unpack a bag you need to put everything on the counters including in front of the TV and if there are 2 people not much counter space left
(3) Walls between rooms are not the thickest
(4) Only mirrors are in the bathroom. But this is probably due to the rooms being so small it is the only place they can fit them. So if wife takes hot showers that steam up the bathroom make sure you get ready first or you will sweat
(5) Pool is great, but there are only 5 lounge chairs. There are hundreds of rooms in this hotel and 5 lounge chairs. There are about 10 other chairs so lets just say they don't want you hanging out at the pool
# 6 - Hot Tub fits 4 adults comfortably if you want to have to make friends. Should be bigger for a hotel this size, especially since they have the room
# 7 - Only 2 people working check in at 4pm on a Saturday for a hotel this size
# 8 - When I was checking in counter agent never mentioned the complimentary coffee in the morning to me though the other agent was mentioning it another guest
# 9 - Was kindly given the room # 666 with no question as to whether this would be okay with me
# 10 - No Security. None. You could walk into this hotel and take the elevator to most guest floors if you wanted to or just walk up the stairs. Only security was around the pool and the gym
# 11 - Gym was very nice. TRX, Free apples, water machine, but the TV on most of the treadmills didn't work.
# 12 - Everything looks pretty, but there were luggage scuff marks all over the walls of our room. However the trim and furnishings were quality. Bluetooth Radio in the room as well which was nice
# 13 - Lastly I booked a "package" that was supposed to get me a complimentary upgrade if available and free wifi in the room. I was not given a wifi code and agent never mentioned an upgrade. When I inquired I was told there was non available though he seemed puzzled why I was asking so beware packages</text><pictures>None<//pictures>< Resp>

</record></dataset><record>
<userid>None</userid><user_name>apphtx< /user_name><Time>1444608000000<//Time>< Rating>
None<//Rating>
<Text>This hotel has a few advantages: the architecture (especially the Garden Court) is superb, the breakfast buffet is large and good, the swimming pool is also very large (especially for a city hotel pool), and it is very well located right on Market street.
I have stayed here by myself and with family many times in the past and was always satisfied with the service. However, this year service has been a catastrophe. I wonder if there has been a change in the upper management of the hotel that could explain that; if this is the case, I'd advise Starwood to let the current manager go...

First, let's talk about rooms and upgrades. As my booking was done through Amex platinum travel, and as a Starwood platinum member, there were 2 reasons to try and get me the room upgrade. While it is based on availability, the Palace has many rooms, and the chance that all rooms corresponding to an upgrade are full is very slim. I traveled on labor day last year and the year before and the Palace was always able to offer me that upgrade, but somehow this year there was no upgrade available at check-in. The young lady at the front desk (it looks like front desk employees have all been changed) told me that there would be something for the following nights if I checked on the following day. I did that... A young guy checked on his computer, and then had to go and see the manager to tell me there was no upgrade available. Either there was something and he should have given it to me, or there was not and he should have said it right away, but why this need to ask the manager?? I suppose the new manager does not like giving the upgrades, and asks all his front desk staff to always check with him so he can deny what customers should have had.
Because we were given a handicap accessible room at check-in, it had a horrible shower that was level with the rest of the bathroom (needless to say, everyone can go into the shower with their dirty shoes..). After being denied the upgrade, we just asked if it was possible to switch rooms (for the same category) to a non-handicap room. The guy checked and saw some free rooms of that category. We did not want to end up in something much smaller, so we asked to see what they had before we could decide to switch or not. Once again, the guy went to see the manager, who didn't want that either.. we would have had to switch to the other room blindly, with the possibility to get into a smaller room!!! In all my hotel stays, I have NEVER seen a manager refuse someone to have a quick look at a room before switching.
If the Palace manager wants to save money by not giving upgrades that people should have (and instead leave the room empty in case someone decided to suddenly check-in..), they should realize that the faithful customers who won't bring their business here again will cause a much bigger loss of money... If the manager also does not like giving upgrades, he/she should make sure to drop out of the Amex Fine Hotels & Resorts program...

Second, breakfast service. While breakfast is good, many people (like my family and I) have coupons for free breakfast (with Starwood or Amex) and that changes the quality of service... Before we were even served coffee, the waiter (whoever that was, it was the same problem every day) asked if we were to bill it to the room or pay with coupons. Service (tip) is included with the coupons, and needless to say the waiters know that and if they know you have coupons, they won't go out of their way to help you. Why would they do it, when they can pamper people who will give them a big tip, and they know that however poor their service is, they will get the same amount of money from you?.. It was very unpleasant to have the waiters come back regularly during the breakfast to ask about the payment method, while family members were waiting forever to have their coffee cup replenished....

Third, room service. This is the first hotel were I was told that emptying the minibar (so we could put some water in it) would cost us $25!!! Other places send someone (to whom you'll give some tip) for free... Then the cleaning of the room was not great. Some papers (used medical pill wrapping) that any good maid service would have trashed were left on my bedside table day after day..We never heard the vacuum cleaner while walking in the corridors while the maids were taking care of other rooms (with the door open).

Fourth, valet parking. It felt like here again, the hotel had fired half the staff compared to the previous years. It took forever to retrieve the car each time we wanted to go out, because valet staff was very much reduced to one or two people.The garage is just opposite the hotel in a small alley, so it's not a distance problem... This is very frustrating when you'd like to continue visiting the many places this city offers to a tourist!

Fifth, the renovation. While I liked the very classic style before the renovation, I don't mind the new modern style of the rooms. However, the bathroom is worse than before, with almost no place to put toiletries around the sink. One improvement though is the high faucet which allows one to wash one's hands without bumping into the sink as was the case before renovation.

With all these issues, the Palace managed to lose a customer who used to come here year after year. I'll miss the Garden Court, and hope that Starwood will quickly realize that if they don't change the way the hotel is currently managed, it will soon run into trouble...<//Text>< Pics>
None<//Pics>

< rate>
None</rate>
< Review>
As an SPG Gold member, I was upgraded to a corner Deluxe Suite of over 600 sq. ft. for our 3-night stay. The suite was well-kept, clean and very comfortable with lots of extra amenities.

The hotel location was the best as we needed to travel from San Fran Airport. The BART station entrance was right outside the hotel on Market Street. It's really easy to travel to all the famous attractions using the MUNI pass by bus, cable car, streetcar and subway.

The front desk, concierge and bell staff were all very helpful. Just one tiny bit of discomfort: the pool water was too cold and the very small whirlpool could only accommodate 4 people, but they were both well-maintained. Occasionally, we could hear the police sirens at night but it's typical staying in downtown hotels in a lot of US big cities.

Overall, my husband and I really enjoyed the grand luxury of The Palace and we would definitely stay there again.<//Review>

Beautiful classical and historic hotel, great location near Financal Disrtict, Union Square, Chinatown and SoMa. But the service is not up to the standard of other Luxury Collection properties world wide. Not sure why its even in the category other than the historic factor. It's too big to offer personalized service. Inconsistent delivery by staff. I would return because of the location but not with the same level of expectation. As a Platinum member didn't feel special or recognized. Front Desk just went through the motion. Room #2 (room 511): 1:45am, went to new room, key did not open door, went down to reception, gave me another room
Room #3 (room 505, adjacent to Room#1): 1:50am, room was freezing, turned up 
thermostat, 2:05am, no change in temperature, requested new room, 2:10am, brought new room key to me
Room #4 (room 681), 2:15am, took luggage to new room, key did not open door, went back down to lobby, front desk attendant came up with me and used master key to let me in room, temperature was a decent 72 degrees, I turned it up to 75 since I was very cold and got to bed about 2:30am. Got up at 7:30am to work. Room was 71 degrees which was fine but still not where I had set the thermostat.
10:00am, checked out, never to return!

<review>I had stayed at this hotel once in the past, and was surprised to find that both I and my roommate were notably allergic to the room.

It is nice that there are some things that you can ALWAYS count on. Excellence at the Palace is one of them. From the moment you walk in the door to the second you leave, it is a quiet, luxurious, comfort knowing that your stay will be comfortable, clean, and well done. My only gripe is that the curbside staff has been consistently lacking my past three visits. When I arrive in my car, I am usually ignored by the staff until I have piled out of the car and uloaded all of my own luggage. The valet is just not at par with the rest of the hotel experience. When they had my car curbside at checkout, the same thing - I had loaded all of my luggage before they had time to help me. Valet is costly, even for the city, so I would hope for a good experience. Once you get in the door, though, it is extraordinary every time.</text>

However it really is down at the heal. The carpet needs replacing both in the public areas and in the rooms. The elevators are slow. The furniture in the rooms is quite beaten up and stained. It badly needs freshening up.

<Rating>None< /Rating>< text>
Great location conveniently next to shops and transportation. We had the standard room and the tall ceilings, color scheme made it spacious / luxurious. Staff was very helpful. The pool was not really heated and when we brought it up, we were heard and the maintenance team came right away. < Gmap_id>
0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb</Gmap_id>
< Text>
Overall the building was very nice but I wouldn't recommended this for folks looking for a place to stay or groups hoping to hosts events. While the hotel itself feels massive and has a very elegant lobby, it had a number of problems.

Cons:
- I have no idea what the housekeeping folks did to the toilet, but see my attached picture for a first hand view of my 'freshly cleaned' toilet :(
- 8-8:30am Housekeeping visits.
- Stains/etc on the fabrics (shower curtains, bed sheets) left the place feeling pretty dirty.
- I guess I didn't intend to spend a ton of time in the room, so the extra space for sitting/deskwork wasn't appreciate while the cramped bathroom was an annoyance when getting ready for the day.
- For the rates they charge for internet, it was really unreliable/slow. I guess they probably give it away to most folks that stay here (myself included), but I experienced constant disconnects/resets and generally very slow traffic that was nowhere near the advertised rates.

Pros:
- The dining staff seemed really friendly and concerned with their work.
- The guest services staff were also really friendly and followed-up on requests.
- In the rooms there were plenty of outlets and USB ports

The kindness of the staff I interacted with was reassuring, but overall this member of the 'luxury collection'  definitely fell short of its name.<//Text>

<date>1467590400000<//date><resp>None< /resp><Text>I was quite excited to stay at this hotel, but we got in much later than expected, and the staff ruined my evening. We pulled up to the hotel. There was one valet, and four cars waiting to be moved. We pulled our own luggage out of the car, dragged it into the hotel because he would not let us take a cart, then we sat and watched while he moved other cars, and left our car running in the streets of San Francisco at midnight. This went on for 15-20 minutes. I was furious.

While I was checking in, Someone put our luggage on a cart then put it in a line of other carts to be taken up to the room. The time to delivery was about 30 minutes. I was exhausted, and just wanted to go to bed. I wanted to take my own things so I could move on with my night. He said fine, but I had to leave the cart. We said it would take 5 minutes and we would bring the cart back. He said no. So here we are, exhausted at midnight, dragging 4 bags and a cooler between the 2 of us in a tux / dress and heels, in a Category 6 hotel we paid a small fortune to stay in - while a bellman, a valet, and 2 check in people stared at us while we struggled to get up to our room. All the while a car is sitting in the road waiting to be taken. 

I was in shock! It's unfortunate, because the room was awesome. It was comfortable, beautiful, ornate, luxurious, and the heated toilet seat was to die for. Our family spent 4 nights at Palace hotel. We absolutely enjoyed our experience. I stayed over 170 nights in SPG hotel in last year alone. So I had seen a lot of rooms.This hotel is a hidden gem! The property is a beautifully maintained historical building. However, the room is very well updated with modern utilities. We never felt we stayed in a 100_ years old hotel. The location is excellent, close to financial district and Union Square. The best part of palace Hotel is the staff: we encountered amazing reception, wonderful valet and helpful room service team. < Rate>

<Text>I checked in and received a nice welcome from the desk agent, but no upgrade from the room booked. The room was clean and very comfortable, with Gilchrist and Soames product in the bathroom and 2 bottles of complimentary water. The hallways are very noisy and I could hear clear conversations coming from adjoining rooms. Soundproofing here is an issue and was disruptive of sleep. My main concern had to do with the lack of cofeemakers in the rooms. The hotel has elected to put out a coffee cart, which is promptly removed at 10 am - none of which was explained to incoming guest. When I returned for coffee, it was gone and I called guest relations. I got the obligatory tart "sorry" from the male agent, along with a suggestion I could order room service (at ridiculous prices). At this price point, the coffee should have been offered complimentary all morning, and it detracted from the ambience of the hotel. The location can't be beat, and it is literally right next to the Montgomery Street BART and Muni station. Other than the location, I can get more for my money (and my Starwood status) elsewhere.<//Text>< Pics>

<name>Catalina66< /name><time>1360454400000</time><Rating>None</Rating><Review>We booked last minute through the Starwood website and got a great rate. We were pleased to receive an upgrade to a Junior Suite upon check in with a City View. The rooms are always beautifully appointed, with luxurious bedding & robes and the complimentary water bottles are something we really appreciate. A new addition to the room is the Keurig coffee maker, which is even more convenient than the complimentary coffee in the lobby. We enjoyed some great cocktails and the AMAZING truffle fries down in the Pied Piper bar, which was bustling on a Friday evening. We had a rather surly man expediting our food, but our waitress was friendly and efficient. WIFI is an extra cost, which didn't affect us, but would have been more problematic if our kids had joined us. Also, valet parking has skyrocketed from $44 three years ago to $59! I had anticipated this and chose to park in the garage around the corner, which is only $25 for 24 hours. San Francico is an expensive parking city, so I can't really fault them for this, particularly as the valets are SO helpful and omnipresent and really work hard if you do choose to valet your car. Overall, it is our favorite property in the City and we can't wait to go back!<//Review><pics>None</pics>< Response>

<UserId.>111889258893089665092</UserId.><response>None<//response>< Gmap_id>

< username>
TennisGirl< /username>
<Date>1497225600000</Date><rate>None<//rate>< Text>
From the moment we walked into the lobby of the Palace, I knew our short 24 hour stay would be one to remember. The absolutely gorgeous display of flowers in the main lobby looked like botanical garden display. Lush and lively, the colors added to classic d√©cor of the lobby.

Check-in: The Platinum/Gold SPG line was short, there was only 1 person in front of us. We were promptly checked in within minutes. 

Lobby/Common Areas ‚Äì with so many new hotels that have gone under renovation, I love that even after the major upgrades last year, the Palace has kept it‚Äôs timeless beauty. The Garden Court and GC Lounge Bar have been refreshed with hues of greys and cream. The gorgeous crystal chandeliers and magnificent glass ceilings have all been maintained meticulously.

Room: I had used a Suite Night upgrade and was upgraded to a Superior Suite. But, since we were starting our Anniversary tour with SPG (we spend 2 to 5 weeks every summer with SPG to celebrate our Anniversaries and birthdays) and we were also hosting another couple, I had requested something special for our special day. Casey, Assistant Director of the Front Desk, delightfully upgraded to one of the newly renovated Palace Suites. We loved every inch of the suite. 
Our room was a corner suite that overlooked Market Street. Each window had a small seating ledge where we could sit and watch the world go by. Market was lined with Pride flags, which was such a nice sight to see. The living room was furnished with modern and chic d√©cor. We loved the chandelier and art that graced the walls. Our bedroom had a large King poster bed and a chaise lounge in front. The bathroom had double sinks, a deep bathtub and a separate stand up shower. The bathroom amenities were plentiful and when we needed more toiletries, housekeeping was quick to bring them up. I love all the Gilchrest and Soames toiletries ‚Äì all very luxurious. Our friends stayed in the fold out sofa bed. For a sofa bed, it was quite comfortable. 

Anniversary Welcome ‚Äì We were greeted to an array of chocolate covered strawberries and a delectable bottle of Chandon, extended tirage. We also were given 2 handwritten note cards to wish us well. 

Service ‚Äì I cannot give enough kudos to the Palace Staff. The front desk staff were kind and assisted when they could. I would like to highlight one particular staff member who has continually made our stays so special ‚Äì Casey ‚Äì Assistant Director. Casey has helped us in the past and never ceases to amaze me with his level of professionalism and how he goes out of his way to ensure our stays are the best they can be. He secured our upgrade and lovely welcome Anniversary greeting. When we realized we had left our wine carrier with a very special 2006 Justin Isosceles in our room, I reached out to Casey. It was found and will find it‚Äôs way back to us. From start to finish, Casey and the Palace staff could not have been more helpful. We had a little glitch with our breakfast reservation and the use of our Platinum Amenity (breakfast in the Garden Court hotel). It didn‚Äôt end up getting worked out where we could have breakfast, but I was able to ask for a swap out of the breakfast for drink coupons (Gold Amenity). FYI ‚Äì breakfast ends at 10:30am on Saturdays and Sundays, a little early for us, but lovely if you are an early bird. 

Pied Piper ‚Äì We love the new and improved bar. It kept it‚Äôs classic look, but is nice and shiny now. The bartenders made excellent craft cocktails. I highly recommend a Manhattan and a French 76 (75 with vodka).

Thank you again for yet another fabulous SPG stay. We can‚Äôt wait to continue celebrating in Mexico and San Diego over the next few weeks with SPG.<//Text>

However, food matters most to me, so I would not come here again on my own initiative.< /Review>

The Palace Hotel is beautiful, and more than comfortable - the rooms I had felt luxurious. The hotel itself has been cared for with pride. Because it was an anniversary, I received a wonderful upgrade to my rooms which I will always remember with joy. The Palace employees were unfailingly friendly and helpful; a better welcome cannot be imagined. I would recommend the Palace Hotel without fail to anyone who wished to make their stay in San Francisco special. The odd little lapses were small: slippers but no robes in the closet, paper coffee cups instead of ceramics, room service without a condiments caddy, housekeeping that didn't include replacing wine glasses, bath salts and a few other items.</Review>

Our first impression was very positive. The entrance and main lobby was gorgeous. The staff checking us in and out we're also kind and pleasant. At check in we had requested one of the beds have foam pillows and one have feather pillows. Unfortunately we had to call two more times and did not get the pillows till almost 11pm. I am a patient person but to not even be acknowledged after 16 minutes does not speak od quality service, much less luxury. Very disappointing overall.< /Review>

< review>
Had a two-day ricochet through SF, and chose the Palace in the hopes that this Luxury Collection property would give me a little bit more than the Spartan-cool comfort I'm used to at W properties. The staff made the experience.

Points of note:
- Warm and friendly staff upon check-in, and throughout my stay.
- A Concierge that could teach classes in resourcefulness and suggesting "just the thing you're looking for" in area dining.
- Very comfortable beds (beware if you think you're just going to take a 30-minute nap).
- Location, location, location!
- Kyo-Ya. Go ahead - try the restaurant in the hotel. You just might thank me.

Protip from a hyper-active New Yorker up at 6AM on a Saturday - order room service coffee/breakfast. Nobody else nearby will be open to serve you.<//review>

< user_name>
Eric McPherson<//user_name>
<time>1552059444960</time><Rate>1< /Rate><review>PROS: could location but I guess pretty much everything in San Francisco is. Relatively renovated rooms and bathrooms although the hotel itself is a typical old hotel with very cheap renovations, lacking any decent artwork, upgraded common areas, for example room has very cheap lighting.air filters and intake in the room or a filthy dirty and when I call to maintenance to change the filters one of the two filters in our suite was missing, no big shocker there.  very good restaurant staff and service, decent buffet but like most Marriott properties overpriced.

CONS: I now clearly understand why this property was $261 a night when all the other nicer category properties in San Francisco we're $600 - $700.  Upon arrival not a single bellman or employee outside nor even inside the entrance doors to help with v heavy bags as my wife and our 11 year old daughter push them up the ramp. shockingly the Bell desk was immediately in front of the entrance door and the man sitting there never even bothered to look up much less get up and help. The woman behind us exactly the same. We took our own backs for the room, not a single offer by anyone including reception to help with bags.  Absolutely astounding that Marriott nickels and dimes their Platinum member is by giving continental breakfast and charging for expresso, $9 none the less,when for example coffee is free.  took time to voice all these complaints to Brendan the duty manager and of course, there wasn't a single response or acknowledgement by email, any small gift in the room, and no communication to any of the issues have been addressed or resolved. In fact following morning once again I found myself arguing with the waiter overcharging for expresso.  Quite frankly, it's not a bad hotel overall but considering Marriott has the audacity to call it the luxury collection, completely fulfills my expectations of Marriott. I stayed at the Hyatt centric fisherman's wharf last time I was here for less money in the room service including Bell service and say request for the complete opposite in a positive way.< /review>< pics>

<Text>Room was spacious enough and had neat architecture elements, but that's where the good parts end.

First, in the bathroom, one of the plastic cups was used - out of the plastic bag, WET, and put on top of the other cup as if it was new. Also, draft from the windows, and in SF, that's cold. Sink, if you turn on the water and aren't careful, you'll have Niagra fall like pressures come rushing out and get everything wet, and to make matters worse, the drain was pretty severely clogged - and the lever to control the drainage - completely broken.

Second, the doors and walls are SO thin, starting at 6AM, I could hear every person walking by, talking, etc.

Finally, when I checked in, was given a choice amongst 250 points, free internet, and something else. I chose free internet, and was told to just sign up for any of the options I get presented on the browser. Well, to my surprise, I looked at my eFolio in the morning, and I got charged...called the front desk, no pickup. Had to go downstairs and take care of it there.

For a "luxury" hotel, this really missed the mark.<//Text>< Pics>

<Review>The hotel itself, is a beautiful building.

We arrived during the strike. I received no warning from the hotel. I did receive an email about a week earlier from the AASLD, the conference I travelled to attend. I received a ‚Äúspecial rate‚Äù of 339/night for a single king room through the conference. Because of the late notice, and the fact that I received this discounted rate through the conference website, I chose not to cancel and book at another hotel.

We arrived to no valet/bell service, and had to walk through a cloud of weed/hot garbage smell and screams to get to the reception counter.

Upon check-in, were informed that there would be no room service for the duration of our stay. We were ‚Äúupgraded‚Äù to another room on the other side of the hotel which would be ‚Äúquieter.‚Äù I admit we could not hear the strike from this room. The window looked out across the courtyard to a brick wall.

I have stayed in cleaner rooms at two star hotels. There were dirty rings from glasses and greasy fingerprints on the table.  We did not have toiletries re-stocked and our trash was not emptied daily.

The room was pretty, with high ceilings and a comfortable king bed. No coffee/tea or minibar was available in the room. We did have some complementary bottled water on arrival, which was not restocked.

During my stay I used the side entrance to Jessie street as it is closest to the conference center. On my way to the conference I was harassed and shamed by some union representative for not changing my reservation.

On the morning of check out we had planned to have breakfast in the atrium. We sat ourselves and were ignored for a full 25 minutes. We were not even offered water. At that point we decided to get breakfast around the corner at the Grove. I got eggs florentine and a latte for 15 dollars which is what the hotel cafe charges for a plain yogurt.

When we returned to the hotel, we asked to have our vehicle brought around to the side entrance so we wouldn‚Äôt have to wait in the noise/smell associated with the picket line. We were informed they would ‚Äúhave to get a manager‚Äù to approve that. We took our own luggage across the street and located our vehicle in the parking garage.

I just received a receipt for my stay. I was charged 84 dollars per day for an ‚Äúoversized vehicle‚Äù which they define as >9 feet tall. I will be contesting this charge.

Very disappointing stay. I paid 1500 dollars for a three night ‚Äúluxury‚Äù experience when no luxury services were available.</Review><pics>None<//pics>< gmap_id>

We have stayed in 50 starwood hotels over the past 6 years, including several luxury collection hotels. This hotel has been the least satisfactory of any stay. The room is quite basic, which is acceptable, but the bathroom is below typical starwood level and even included some mold. The walls are paper thin, in which we were kept up at night by our neighbors basic conversation, prompting a need to call the front desk. The desk was responsive and did respond however.
Overall, the hotel was poor enough we considered forgoing our starpoints an moving to another hotel in the area. It is unlikely we would return, and that is something we have never said about a starwood property</text>

< Text>
My girlfriend and I stayed at the Palace for a weekend stay-cation earlier this month. The hotel is beautiful and the accommodations were fair.

I reserved the room with my credit card and my girlfriend put her credit card down for incidentals upon checkin. After our stay, my girlfriend noticed two large charges on her card from the Palace. I called to ask what they were for and it turns out the hotel charged both her and my card for the full amount of our stay.This was shocking, but the Palace acknowledged the mistake, apologized, and promised to give my girlfriend the money back. However, it's been three weeks since reporting this to the Palace and they still haven't given the money back. I have called repeatedly, and each time they tell me they will look into it and call me back. They never called back and I had to go to the hotel three times to talk to them. The money still hasn't been returned and I am disappointed with the staff has handled this entire ordeal.

I urge those staying in the Palace to review their bank statements with care in the event this happens to you, too.</Text>

<text>We stay at the Palace for 1-2 nights at a time, generally 1-2 times per year for pleasure. We like the hotel. On this trip, the AC made a fairly loud clunk each time it turned on/off which was a problem because we had it on throughout the night due to unseasonably warm temperatures over the 2013 holidays. The pillows were too large to be useful, and next time we'll remember to ask for reasonable pillows @ the front desk. We left a note about the AC.

On the plus side, this is a classic historic hotel with great rooms and ambiance. It has very comfortable beds, the best showers and soap!

I am a Platinum member and stayed at the hotel on October 19th. I have two complaints.
First- When I ldeparted I left my Beats headset on the nightstand next to the bed in room 612.
While at the airport in SFO I called and spoke to Security/Lost&Found's contact Michael. He promised to immediately check the room and then call me back. 
No Call Back.
I called on October 25th and left a message for Michael. 
No Call back. 
On October 27th I called and asked to speak to a manager in the same department. I was switched to Jphn's voicemail and left a message. 
No Call Back....
On October 30th I called and asked to speak to a Manager in any department and was switched to Sarah. She finally solved the situation and of course my headset was never recovered. 
After taking 10 days I had very little hope that they would have been found. 
Seocnd- they dining arrangements at the hotel are very poor considering the quality of the asset. I attempted to have a business dinner and make a reservation for dinner. They don't take reservations. Then you have to walk through the bar and into a very Spartan room to be seated for dinner. The food was good but the ambience was not.<//review>

This hotel has flair and history combined with a great location. The feeling of the grand days of SFO in a tastefully modernised building. Only the flaky, costly internet reception and the somewhat poky, antiquated bathrooms in the smaller rooms stops it from getting 5 stars. <text>This century old nine story hotel stands immediately adjacent to both the BART Montgomery Street Station and the Monadnock Building, and across Market Street from Lotta's Fountain. Elegant and luxurious since 1909 it has remained an important San Francisco landmark as well as host to many of the city's great events. The "Garden Court" is beautiful and inviting. Staff is amiable and rooms are comfortable.<//text></record></dataset><record>

<Response>None<//Response><Name>jetsettr<//Name><user_id>None<//user_id>< Rating>
None</Rating>
< Review>
We came to the Bay Area two weeks ago to get married in Muir Woods. Even though the ceremony was in Marin and weekend activities were all in Napa and Half Moon Bay, we chose to splurge and spend all four nights at the beautiful Palace hotel in San Francisco, excited about the old world elegance, grandeur, and world-class service. It was out of our way, but we didn't care. I indicated when I made the reservation two months prior that it was our wedding, and even took the time to e-mail the hotel GM prior to our arrival (he never responded). Upon arrival, we were told that there were no upgrades available. I found this odd seeing as I had informed them 2 months ago that it was a once-in-a-lifetime occasion, and had also taken the time to e-mail the GM directly. I figured no worries, they probably had plenty of full-rate customers paying for those rooms. We took the room we were given and were surprised to see a beautiful bouquet of flowers waiting for us. I was heartened and touched at what I thought was a lovely consolation gesture for not being able to upgrade us. I was mistaken - it was a lovely gesture from personal friends of ours, not the hotel.

Our room on the 8th floor was elegantly decorated (old-world, but not outdated) and clean. The view was nothing to talk about - looking directly into the windows of adjacent office buildings. The bed was extremely comfortable, and the pillows fluffy almost to the point of discomfort. There was no coffee maker in the room, but happily the fridge was one of those that actually had tons of empty space for guests' items, not just minibar stock. The coffee at the in-house Ghirardelli cafe was to die for anyway. Water pressure in the shower was fantastic. I agree with the other reviewer that noted the lack of available electrical outlets in the room. Also, as another reviewer stated, the walls are VERY thin. I was able to hear the telephone conversation of the guest in the next room quite clearly, as well as numerous guests in the hallways at 2am. As there seem to be a lot of families staying there, the pool at 9pm on a Friday looked like a kids' water park in the summertime. The hot tub was filled with teenagers. We promptly walked right back out and the spa attendant gave us a sympathetic look and said, We open in the morning at 5am! :) All staff we encountered were polite, but not particularly gracious.

Hotel location was fantastic, we were able to walk to the mall, the Embarcadero, etc. Cabs were plentiful and easy to hail.

I must say that every step of our journey from our home state of FL, people went out of their way to acknowledge our occasion and make it special for us (complimentary champagne on the flight, complimentary champagne at dinner, personalized menus, an upgraded rental car, etc - all without us asking). However, not once did the Palace acknowledge our occasion or do anything to make it special for us. I guess I had wrongly assumed that it was things like this where hotels such as the Palace shine - where they separate themselves from their more standard competitors. We were looking for it to be a special stay at an old-world-elegance hotel. Instead It was a very ordinary stay at old-world-elegance hotel. In fact, by the time Sunday morning had rolled around, we decided not to give the Palace Hotel any more of our money and cancelled the Garden Court brunch reservation for four.

I'm giving an overall rating of Average because it was exactly that. There was NOTHING special about this stay at this hotel, and I'm quite disappointed in having personally reached out to the general manager and then receiving not even so much as an acknowledge or reply. For the amount of money that we spent to stay here, we quite frankly expected more.</Review>
< gmap_id>
0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb</gmap_id>

< review>
I tend to stay at this hotel more often than the other SPG properties in SF. However, they also seem to have the most variety of room types ranging from TINY to luxurious. With SPG status I have no problems booking here when the hotel is not sold out because I can usually get moved from the smallest room to something a little more comfortable. However, if you get stuck with a traditional room you may not enjoy your experience too much just because of the size of the room. The hotel amenities are some of the best and you definitely feel that you are staying in a more upscale hotel compared to the other SPG properties in town ‚Äì thicker towels, luxurious robes, the staff are genuinely more friendly. Since I stay at this hotel often I generally receive a note from the manager as a welcome. It‚Äôs never expected but it tells me that they acknowledge that I spend time at their property and it makes me smile.< /review>

<userid>None</userid><user_name>Halo123< /user_name><Time>1501459200000< /Time><rating>None< /rating><text>The hotel seems updated and relatively new. It has a beautiful lobby and entrance.
However, there were some things that made me wonder. For example, they had no one time/ throwaway slippers in the room. Only bathrobes. We had to call the concierge to get them and waited a good 15 min just to be able to go to the pool. Noone there except us had slippers there either so I assume they simply don't provide them. Kind of weird for a hotel this class to not providd basic amenities any truck stop hotel chain has.
Also, internet costs $15 per day. You may use internet in the lobby for 1 hour every day with 1 device per room. For SPG members internet is free but only if they were members before checking in and if they booked through the hotel website. That's ridiculous to charge for something any starbucks gives out for free. I really don't get it why luxury chains do that. Just mark up your nightly prices by $15 if you need the money that desperately. 
In summary, definitely one of the more comfortable places to stay in SF, staff was friendly but hotel policies and management should seriously reconsider some of their practices.< /text><pictures>None< /pictures><response>None< /response>< Gmap_id>

<Review>I have an office in San Francisco and over the last 15 years, I have stayed in a lot of hotels in the City. I have spent more and I have spent less, but I stay at The Palace every chance I get. The hotel couldn‚Äôt be more convenient, the entry to the hotel is beautiful, the Garden Court is exquisite, the fitness center is well equipped, but the reason I stay at the hotel is the staff. I have stayed in boutique hotels in the City that when my room key didn‚Äôt work the front desk clerk didn‚Äôt remember checking me in, a total of an elapsed 5 minutes. That just doesn‚Äôt happen at The Palace; the front desk staff, to the person, is attentive and extremely helpful, the concierge can improve any trip, the fitness center attendant is one of the most pleasant people I have ever met, and the bell staff handles large groups capably and remains cordial in the process. I know some people think some of the rooms are small, but my experience is the rooms are typical to large, particularly, for a downtown hotel. We‚Äôll be in San Francisco twice this summer for vacation; I could stay any place I want; I‚Äôll be at The Palace.<//Review></record>

< userid>
117390326887098008079<//userid>
< Text>
Good hotel in a historic building right off market Street. Good location although is a little dead on weekends. Nice breakfast spread including hot and cold options served in an amazing atrium. Rooms are modern, comfortable and quiet. Many lights make up for rooms that are on the interior lightwell. Those rooms are really quiet but less light. Good fitness center and lap pool, which is cool and nice for doing laps. Hottub was under repair during my visit. Overall comfortable, quiet hotel with good amenities in business district of San Francisco.< /Text>

am1112014</name>
<Time>1392508800000</Time><Rating>None< /Rating>< review>
Combine noisy location, with paper thin walls between rooms, and a faulty fire alarm system prompting evacuation at 1:15 am, and you have the Palace Hotel. As you won't be able to sleep, you might want to use internet, which is ridiculously expensive. if you manage to doze off, the fire alarm will certainly wake you again bright and early, then repetitive announcements rubbing in the fact that the fire alarm is false and you don't need to evacuate will keep you up until you stagger out into Market Street for the relative piece and quiet of morning rush hour. The hotel staff is really good at apologizing, suggesting serious amount of practice, further suggesting that I am not the only person unhappy with this establishment.

If you still decide to stay here, you should hope that the construction across the street has been completed, or at least they talked to the worker who thought it to be a good idea to throw metal drawers and other garbage out of a third floor window into a metal container on the street for half an hour at 11:30 pm.</review>

<user_name>Aaron M. Putman</user_name><date>1502294564935<//date><Rate>4<//Rate>< Text>
Great service. Beautiful lobby, garden court, pool and bar. Expensive but you get what you pay for. Very posh and historic. The rooms are very clean. The elevators are quick and you don't wait long for one. Easy access to the Ferry Building and Union Square. The only thing is since it is on the edge of the financial district there is quite a bit of traffic and very hard to move around in a car. Walk don't drive. And if you are driving head west not east. Also as this is San Francisco the homeless population is large. They don't bug you but they are a constant reminder of the issues that this city has with drugs and homelessness.</Text>

<name>Jelly< /name><time>1339977600000<//time>< Rate>
None< /Rate>
< review>
This hotel is in a geat location and is really nice. My only critique would be the bedding. The bed had a down duvet instead of a blanket and sheet. While this seems like a luxary at first, I find it to be a negative. The bed didn't have a top sheet or a blanket. This means that the only choice is duvet or nothing. Its too hot for use year round, resulting in needing to boost the AC unit. (wasted energy). I was still hot, meaning that I and every other guest, was sweating on the duvet. Im pretty sure they are NOT cleaned inbetween guests. ICK. Now that I think of it- this would explain why the room has a slightly unclean smell even after the maid had been there. Advice- replace the Duvet with a cotton (washable) blanket.<//review>

<user_id>None<//user_id>< Pics>
None<//Pics>
<text>Our stay was excellent from the moment we checked in to check out. There were three of us and we reserved one superior suite.
I have to say the Couchbed didn't have a good mattress so the first night sleep wasn't so great but after complaining they changed it to an extra bed which was as good as the Kingsize one.
The breakfast area is really beautiful and the breakfast is good as well, just the 7$ extra charge for platinum guests for the Palace breakfast is a little bit unnecessary regarding the general hotel price.
In room dining was excellent.
Parking is the most expensive I have seen in SF with 72$ but behind the hotel is another garage for just 35$ per night.
In the end its really worth the price and one of the best hotels in SF to stay in.</text>< user_name>
Blanc</user_name>

<Rate>None</Rate><Name>solarsoar< /Name>< time>

<text>The Palace is a luxurious hotel with lots of old charm to the architecture. Overall, the housekeepers were very thorough and the staff in general was very friendly and accommodating.

Part of the problem with such a high class place is that you expect everything to be perfect. A couple of times I called the front desk and the phone just rang and rang. One time, the front desk did answer, but put me on hold and never got back. The Concierge though was very responsive and friendly. While we received a Deluxe Grand Room, there wasn't efficient use of the space, specifically there were only two upright chairs to sit, not lounge in. In a room on the third floor, during the night and early morning we can hear the buses and trolleys on the street. The windows are not very well insulated, showing the age of the building. And for a place in San Francisco, there's no soy milk available with the free coffee in the morning, even when you ask.< /text>< Response>

<Rating>None< /Rating><gmapID>0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb</gmapID>< review>
This is a beautiful hotel in a great location. Walking distance to many area attractions and shopping. We stayed with our young son for two days prior to moving on to Napa. Upon check in Gold SPG status was acknowledged and late check out was offered. Had some issues with the HVAC that were addressed immediately. Heated toilet seat was awesome! Loved the complimentary coffee and tea in the morning. Such a nice feature. Lobby was beautiful. Was able to have a glass of wine down there. 

The one negative was the pool. It was freezing. One of the reasons we chose this particular hotel was because we wanted our son to be able to enjoy the pool. Sight seeing with your parents can get old, so the pool was the one specific thing we had for him to enjoy. It was so cold, everyone in the pool area was crowded into the hot tub. It was ridiculous and made the experience very unpleasant. Please heat the pool. It's so nice, but not enjoyable when it's ice cold.<//review>

< username>
salo9979<//username>
< userid>
None</userid>
< Review>
This hotel is lovely - old, historic, grand. But it is IS old. That means one has to keep in mind a couple of things:
1. If you want new, simple, elegant design, this is not the hotel for you.
2. If you want big, luxurious bathrooms, not the hotel for you.
3. If you want privacy or any sense of sound-proofing in your room, this is not the hotel for you.
BUT:
1. If you want to proximate to all that San Francisco has to offer, you can't beat the location.
2. If you want to experience grand service and surroundings, the Pied Piper and the Garden Court are unmatched.
3. If you want a room that resembles nothing so much as a lovely little ring box, you should definitely give it a try.
A couple of items to note:
1. This hotel gets crowded. It's large; check-in times can be very crowded in the small-ish area used for those purposes. There are also many public tours that meet in the foyer, and many private events that happen in the grand spaces - so don't expect to enjoy peaceful tranquility in the public spaces of this hotel.
2. The team working the cab stand, valet, New Montgomery Street entrance are INSANELY GOOD. Props to them!
3. The Concierge team is great, although they can be overwhelmed at certain times of the day.
4. The beds and linens are lovely - very comfortable and well-maintained.
5. The TV remotes are too complicated for easy use; and a channel guide would be helpful.<//Review>

None</Rating>

< user_id>
