< user_name>
Leslie16<//user_name>
< Time>
1414972800000</Time>
<rate>None</rate>< Text>
I spent 25 minutes when booking our reservation with a Starwood representative to get the rooms that we needed for our brief stay to be placed on the same floor....one with a king/queen the other needed two doubles. In order to achieve this I was told by a Starwood representative that my husband and I needed to book 2 grand deluxe rooms which was the only way that we could insure getting the rooms near each other on the same floor. It was important to us that are two rooms were on the same floor as we were traveling with our children. In fact my husband and I chose a smaller room then we initially desired for ourselves in order to accommodate the availability of what was on hand. When hanging up with Starwood I was insured by our representative,who had coordinated directly with the hotel reservations staff, that we would have two grand deluxe rooms with the appropriate bed requirements on the top floor of the hotel that were near each other. That was our expectation when we checked in. Simple enough.

We checked into the hotel around 6:30 at night only to find that nothing about the reservation was as I had booked. Once placed in our rooms(Which were on an entirely different floors , each with king beds), we had to move within moments due to the screaming children that were dismantling the room next to us. The hallway leading to the end of the Corredor in which our room was located was littered with cribs, dirty reminants from room service carts and sounded and looked more like a Chucky cheese than it did a luxury hotel. Our second room which was also book-ended by extremely loud people did not have the two double beds that we booked. Both of our rooms were entirely unacceptable and would have made it impossible to have a second's peace for the 30 hours we were to be in San Francisco. The moment when we alerted the front desk of the conditions of the rooms and the error of the booking I was told that my reservations were merely "requests" and that the hotel could only do their best to accommodate those "requests" not guarantee them. From the time we checked in we then waited approximately two hours to be put into two new rooms that were in fact on the same floor though one was a standard room and quite a bit smaller than the room that we booked only to be told that it was a "grand deluxe" room "class". Being beyond reason at this point I found myself arguing the lack of space, additional windows and bathroom size, to prove my point. The other room was a handicap room with a bench in the shower, etc....needless to say, these were not the rooms we booked nor the conditions we expected from a luxury hotel. I was a little more than peeved at the runaround and lack of continuity in the hotel staff's addressing of this issue. At no point in time did a manager apologize for the inconvenience and tell us to go sit in the bar, have a drink on them while they sorted out the rooms and had our bags delivered to the new accommodations . At no point in time was there a note apologizing for leaving us walking about the hotel for two hours at 7 o'clock at night. After an 8 hour drive through a rainstorm from LosAngeles Unfortunately we missed our dinner reservation in San Francisco for one of our nights there and needed to go down to the restaurant at the hotel where we dropped $300 on the dinner bill just to grab a bite while we waited to land somewhere in the hotel.. Some of the front desk people dealing with the reservations were kind others were snooty(only one in particular). I have never seen a hotel that is part of the luxury hotel brand have such an inconsistent staff. At no point in time did the manager intervene. The hotel botched our stay and we felt as though we were the complaining high-need patrons. Never was there an ,"I'm sorry". All we kept being told was, "I see"....code for ,"you're a bother and I don't care".

The hotel does have an impressive lobby and lower floor. The rooms do have lovely beds with wonderful sheets. The ceilings are high and if we had wanted a standard room it was quite nice as far as standard rooms go. I really would've been quite happy with hotel had there not been the complete inconsistency in staff and had our accommodations not been so botched. It doesn't matter how magnificent a hotel is if the service is not there. We've stayed at many luxury hotel brand hotels over the years and have never been disappointed until now. The entire point of booking such a hotel is to have the service that one grows to expect. In my opinion the hotel should have comped our stay or made some gesture towards trying to make up for basically what was a lost evening on our first night in San Francisco and was a terrible way to celebrate ours son's 16th birthday evening. Seeing as we were only there for two nights, that was Half of our stay. Our expectations had been to drive in, check-in, freshen up, have cocktails and enjoy a lovely evening out in the city with our children....not babysit a room change with no place to get ready for the night out.

As a side-note, we were told that the hotel will be renovating and be done sometime in the spring. Keep that in mind when booking for this hotel as I'm sure that it will be quite loud on the floors near the construction.</Text>

<Date>1524873600000<//Date><rating>None<//rating>< review>
Hotel is very old. My room was connected to the room next door by a door. I was having a very normal conversation with my sister when the guest next door started banging on the door asking us to quiet down. I suppose there was absolutely no noise insulation. Given that I paid a premium rate for this hotel I would expect updated rooms and better noise insulation. 
Also the hotel's location was very inconvenient for Uber drop offs, Several times drivers asked me if they could drop me off a block away since there was simply no way to turn over to the street from Market which doesn't' allow non-commercial vehicles. 
There are much better and more convenient SPG hotels in the area that I would choose to stay in before I book here again.</review>

<Rating>None</Rating><text>This was the first time I had experienced the so-called luxury of the Palace Hotel and I was not impressed. Front desk staff were pompous, ill-informed and downright inefficient. It took three phone calls and an hour to get them to deliver keys to the room.

The rooms themselves, at least the two I saw first hand, were in dire need of repair. The in-room information package was a cheap, soiled photocopy, which had obviously been in the room for many weeks, despite the introductory letter saying it was a temporary solution while the permanent materials were being printed.

Breakfast service was poor, slow, inattentive and that's being kind. The staff wasn't able to fulfill a simple request for two cappuccinos before I had completed eating my breakfast despite there being no lack of personnel and very few guests at the time.

The one exception to the string of inadequate experience was the concierge, who was knowledgable, helpful and pleasant. It's a pity the rest of the hotel came nowhere close to her level of professionalism.

I will not be returning to the Palace and definitely recommending that others look elsewhere or be prepared to be disappointed.</text><Pictures>None< /Pictures>< resp>

<Review>I would like to follow-up on a previous experience at the Garden Court last December.

My mother and father came to visit this past weekend and I made a reservation through Jamie Klages for Sunday brunch. The meal was wonderful (fresh food, great variety, attentive service) and our server - Elena - was most helpful and patient (Dad wanted to take pictures and she gladly assisted more than once). At the end of the meal, Jamie took the time and effort to present my mom with a beautiful, fresh birthday / mother's day cake. She also took care of the entire bill (I was expecting just my mother's portion to be complimentary). When we tried the cake, it became apparently how much thought and effort Jamie / the kitchen team took to ensure the ingredients would be compatible with my mother's pallet.

I wanted to express my gratitude for making my mom's birthday/mom day celebration such a memorable one and more than making up for the disappointing experience we had last year.

This is the reason why I have been and will continue to be a supporter of the SPG group. Thank you again.</Review><Pics>None< /Pics><Response>None< /Response><gmap_id>0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb< /gmap_id></record>

<Text>When I chose the hotel for a family reunion celebrating my parents 59th wedding anniversaryand my sister's new medical practice, I wanted a place that was fancy enough to impress my parents but it would give my sister and I somethings to do while we were there.
Although I rented a car and San Francisco I didn't realize that this hotel was in front of the central hub of San Francisco Mass. transit.
There is even Ghiradelli's in the lobby serving ice cream and treats much nicer my opinion that the original site at Fisherman's Wharf..

I live in Florida and have a pool that I never use because it is too hot, but I went down to the indoor pool with my sister and family every day and had a blast.

We were there for 10 days and every one of the maids, maintenance people, poolside concierge, reception desk people, valets and bellhops were all helpful, professional and made us feel like family.The place is spotless and the beds and comforters are yummy. My parents can't stop talking about how nice your Hotel is.

I have traveled all over the planet and have stayed at five-star hotels worldwide, but I never had a better time than at the "Palace."</Text><Pics>None<//Pics>< Resp>

< review>
While this is a beautiful hotel, service is substandard. I arrived for a 3pm check in but the room was not ready until 4:30pm which altered the evening's plans since my wife had planned to wash her hair before dinner and the Opera. We settled for a light meal instead of the dinner we had planned. When I called room service for ice it took 45 minutes for it to arrive. I also called the concierge to ask on what TV channel the Thursday night football game could be seen - they didn't know and it took 30 minutes for them to find out and call me back. After breakfast the following morning we returned to our room to discover the electronic lock no longer worked and had to contact security to get back into our room. I really expect more from a hotel of the stature of the Palace.</review>

<Rating>None<//Rating><pics>None<//pics>< review>
This is now the third time we have stayed at this hotel and EVERY TIME we have checked in we have been made to wait because our room's carpet has needed to be 'shampooed.' I have been in hospitality management before and when hotels have 'overbooked' themselves, they often give this excuse. We were made to wait over an hour for the room. We were not offered any compensation...no money off, no complimentary breakfast, no complimentary cocktails. When asked by different associates in and around the hotel how are stay was, we told them of the issue, only to hear, "Oh, I'm sorry." No one ever offered to 'make it right.' We were even locked out of our room for the second night and had to wait for security to come up with new scanned keys (being made to wait outside our hotel room until help arrived). We paid way to much money to be treated like this. We will never stay at this hotel again. Ever! I'm sure this review will go unanswered.< /review>

< text>
This hotel was recommended by a friend just a day before my trip. I didn't expect much but it was a pleasant surprise especially at the bargain price. The lobby is very luxurious, rooms are elegant but very simple. Bed linens are the top line cotton. I am not sure what is the "thread count" but I am sure it's one of the highest. Towels are not as soft though. Swimming pool and exercise facilities are a nice bonus.</text>

< Review>
Checked in to a long line and obviously unhappy reception area, no smiles whatsoever, asked for Platinum upgrade was told "we are full" - given a city view room, which was not the Deluxe City View King we had booked and were told again "we are full as you can see". Plat amenity offered were some cookies [ seriously? ], took the points.

The sad state were the rooms, stained and tired old carpets, mold in bathroom grout, bruised and tarnished wooden furniture, dust all over [ corners, everywhere from a foot from the floor, tops of paintings etc. ] I am mildly asthmatic so think twice about this place. Talked to a very friendly housekeeper who confirmed the dire state of affairs at The Palace.

I took many pictures to point out to management, though, again, no response.

Called guest services that window latches were both broken and the AC would not function [ it was a warm and sunny day ] - I was told that we were very busy. Needless to say nobody every returned our call despite having inquired 3 times. Swimming Pool was closed and no alternate facilities were offered.

All in all a very sad state of affairs for the Luxury Collection Hotel and Platinum Recognition was equally pitiful.< /Review>

< Text>
We enjoyed our stay here. Our room was very comfortable, and the building is spectacular. In particular our bed was great. Breakfast in the hotel under the glass dome is expensive but worth it for the experience, at least once. The hotel is centrally located and walking distance to key business and tourist destinations, like Moscone center, SF MOMA, the ferry terminal plaza, and Chinatown. There is also a pool and decent looking fitness center, although we didn't use it. We would stay here again.</Text>

< text>
This was our second time to stay at the Palace - we love the ambiance, the old world feel and how special we feel when we stay at this hotel. However, on this occasion, our room (765) was not up to par. There was no bidet toilet seat in our room, but the remote control was mounted on the wall(?). Also, we were unable to turn off the TV with the remote - we had to get up and manually turn the TV off using the button in the back. We called the front desk to have this looked at - they said they were going to send an Engineer up, but after 30 minutes we gave up. Lastly, throughout the night, a fan or motor outside of our room, would kick on and disturb our sleep. We were by the elevators so perhaps that was the cause. Regardless of all these factors, we were travelling with our 2 small children and decided to stay in the room having unpacked all our bags. We love the Palace and will probably stay there again, however this stay was not up to the level that we were expecting.<//text>

<Rate>None<//Rate><review>I stayed at the Palace Hotel in San Francisco for my mom‚Äôs 50th birthday, which was noted at the time of making reservation. When I was checking in, the check-in agent gave me a default room that is the lowest category of all. He then later told me he could give me one (1) category upgrade. I was a bit confused ‚Äî I‚Äôm a SPG Platinum member booked under the Amex Fine Hotels & Resorts program, so the Platinum best-room upgrade entitlement needs to override the Amex FHR rate upgrade. However, the check-in agent, who was apparently a newcomer, didn‚Äôt end up giving us any upgrade, so we were assigned to a default room ‚Äî although I could see plenty of inventory online on the SPG app. 

As you may know, Amex FHR rate comes with free breakfast, $100 F&B credit and late check-out. We requested a 4pm late check-out during check-in, but then we later discovered that the check-in agent forgot to program our keys accordingly and that our keys will expire at 1pm. We requested a new set of keys on three separate occasions and waited for two hours, but they never arrived and we had to go pick them up ourselves. 

What‚Äôs more infuriating happened during afternoon tea service at the garden court. We arrived at the garden court lounge to use our $100 F&B credit at 2pm. We sat and ordered our menu promptly afterwards, but our food didn‚Äôt come until 2:50pm! After 50 minutes! They stood us up for 50 minutes with just tea and we were never offered any apologies. It was appalling ‚Äî and we left the site very, very angry. Again, this was supposed to be all for my mom‚Äôs 50th birthday, and it was all ruined. 

The hotel management has been ignoring my calls, voicemail and emails. I had to have Starwood corporate intervene because the hotel management was so bad.

< text>
This is my second time staying at the Palace hotel. I really did want to love it more than I did. I wonder at what point a "Grand and Historic" hotel just turns into an OLD hotel. Let's keep in mind that this hotel is marketed as a "luxury collection" hotel which is a special designation of Starwood hotels. I expected more from this hotel. The halls were wide and the decor of the hotel gave you that old world feeling. It was quite nice. However, the rooms are on the small side. Even that would be OK but for a Luxury Collection hotel I didn't expect to see stains on the furniture, chips in the paint around the room, marks on the walls, etc. The beds were comfortable and the shower pressure was great. The hotel exit it about 5 feet from the Mongomery Bart/Muni stop as well.</text>

<gmap_id>0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb< /gmap_id><pictures>None<//pictures><date>1384214400000< /date>< text>
First, the Good. The Hotel is in a great location. On Market Street-- right next to a Bart Station and an F-Line Trolley car stop. A+++ The surrounding area felt safe and there were plenty of stores and restaurants. The Hotel itself immediately impresses with the architecture and grand entrance. A+++

Now, the Not-so-good. Once the initial blush of the grand entrance wears off, you really begin to notice the dirty and worn carpet, bubbling plaster and dirty paint and general wear and tear on the fixtures and woodwork. C-

The rooms are comfortable, but lack some of the conveniences you expect from new hotels.

I was extremely surprised to find that they charge for internet access in the room. Wired or wireless. I guess they feel like it is OK since most of the guests are business people and they expense it. D-. It felt like 10 years since the last time I paid for internet in a hotel.

The room had no in-room coffee pot. Again, I can‚Äôt remember the last time I stayed in a hotel without one. I like to have my first cup of coffee, before I‚Äôm ready to get dressed and venture out to a coffee shop. D.

The room had no microwave. Again seems like forever since I stayed in a hotel without one. D.

The bathroom had no vent fan. Which made it very steamy for quite a while after taking a shower. C.

AND the refrigerator that was in the room seemed to have only 2 settings‚ÄîOFF and Frozen. Everything I put in the refrigerator froze one night and thawed the next after I tried to turn it down. F.</text>

<time>1364601600000</time>< Text>
We've stayed at the Palace Hotel for some years now and it's still our hotel of choice in San Francisco. We love the ambience and ths staff is great - from the parking valets to the front desk, we are made to feel welcome. The concierge staff has always been helpful. During ouf recent stay, we found the Pied Piper bar to have become so noisy that it's not pleasant to stop for an evening cocktail. Maybe some changes could be made to have a lower noise level? Our room was short on drawer space but otherwise was just fine. The hot tub seems a bit dated and could use some attention.< /Text>

<review>We had not stayed in the palace for years but the location is now better than the St. Francis as you are 5 mins from Union Square, 1 block from MOMA and museums, short walk to farmers market and The Embarcadero. Rooms are renovated and spacious. We had a lovely king bed, but the pillows were high foam and drapes didn't quite close making sleep a bit tough. . The Palm Court is just as impressive as ever and Maxwells is a livelier mature bar scene. Staff were wonderful immediately fascilitating a solution to a problem we had. Parking is $59 and it's not easy as there are only a couple of slots on busy Montgomery street for valet parking, and you have to double park. We thoroughly enjoyed our stay and will be looking to the palace rather than Union Square hotels.</review><Gmap_id>0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb<//Gmap_id><Date>1399248000000<//Date>< Resp>

< Review>
I was extremely disappointed by my recent stay at the Palace. The hotel is no where near the standard of what I expect from Starwood. Relative to my recent stay at the Westin Gaslamp in San Diego, this hotel was falling apart. The carpets were filthy, the lock to my room did not work properly, TV in my room did not work properly and the lights in the hallway wereout in several places. There was no coffee service and or minibar in the room. The in hotel dining options were limited. While the location is convenient, there was a constant stream of homeless people camped out in various parts of the massive lobby.

I would not stay at the palace again unless there are significant upgrades made.</Review>

< username>
Absolute</username>
<date>1424044800000< /date>< rating>
None<//rating>
<text>My wife and I stayed at The Palace using points, and a SNA (Suite Night Award). I chose The Palace based on other reviews, it's location, and the prestige of staying in a Luxury Collection hotel. Our suite upgrade was granted a few days in advance, and upon arrival we stepped into the shorter SPG line.

Check-in was very smooth, and we were actually upgraded from our upgrade to a superior suite, and chose free breakfast as our amenity. We were located on the 4th floor in a corner location adjacent to Market and New Montgomery,which provided a great view.

The suite was very spacious, with high ceilings and plenty of room. It also had an adjacent sitting room, the same size as the bedroom. The sitting room held a couch, two chairs, a work desk, and a cabinet with another TV on it. There was also a fireplace in the wall, although I doubt it was ever functional recently - just meant for show. The sitting room would be a great place to entertain a group or function; a lot more space than two people would require.

As others have mentioned, the walls of the rooms are very thin. We heard our neighbours quite often through the bathroom wall, as they were a young couple and quite loud in talking and laughing - the only thing we could do was make sure our bathroom door was shut at night to minimize disruption.

Being an older hotel, it is difficult to find plugs in some locations, but it still has it's charm. The Garden Court was closed for cleaning our first day, so we took breakfast in the sports bar, and the Garden Court thereafter.

Breakfast was my only complaint - it was common to arrive for breakfast in the morning and wait between 15 to 30 minutes to be seated, despite plenty of open tables. The Maitre'd didn't seem to be too organized - often seating people who arrived more recently before others, with people continually asking where they were on the list in order to make sure they weren't skipped.

After being seated, it would take several minutes for a waiter to appear; when they did they would take our breakfast card and provide us with coffee and orange juice‚Ä¶ and then never visit our table again. If you wanted more coffee or juice, you'd be better off getting it yourself. It was as if they intentionally avoided everyone but paying customers. The setting of breakfast was beautiful, though!

Clarity on the free breakfast was missing as well - Day 1 we were told we could have everything - both hot and cold meals from the buffet. Day 2 we were only permitted a continental, with no hot food. Day 3 we were permitted all cold buffet items, plus half of the hot items. We were always paranoid about whether or not we would be charged for getting something outside of our included breakfast, which was $7/person more.

The gym and pool are a great feature as well - with plenty of machines in the gym (24 hours), and a large pool (until 10pm). There was a large number of families at the hotel when we were there, which filled up the pool every evening and night - if you're looking for laps go early.< /text>< pictures>
None< /pictures>
< response>
None</response>

<Rating>None< /Rating>< Review>
The hotel should have told me there was a strike going on.   First, not everyone is comfortable crossing a strike for personal or political reasons.  Second, the strike created a lot of noise and made me feel like I was being held hostage in the hotel, as every time I left I was screamed at.  Thirds, the hotel was not full service.  There was no room service.  It was obvious the maid service was weak.  I found women's underwear on my bathroom floor.   I had ZERO toiletries.    And I called to get someone to come up and no one ever showed up.    The whole thing felt forced and was not comfortable.    The price point is ridiculous for what essentially is a 4 Points hotel (zero service).    They should have closed rooms to maintain service.  Short term gains will not pay off.</Review>

<Pics>None</Pics>< Text>
1. Gross garbages in the hallway. When I first checked in at around 4pm yesterday, I saw a garbages(leftover food from room services, bags..) at the hallway. It was 4pm. It was not even early check-in. Today(12/24), I saw them and they were still there. In the afternoon, still there. After having dinner at Pied Piper at 8:40pm, they were still there. Nobody cleaned them for more than a day. Every time I pass the hallway on my way to room, I saw gross leftover stuck in the dish.
2. I talked to the hotel front an hour ago about this but they are still there. He said they will clean right away but maybe right away meant tomorrow for him.

Pied Piper.
1. I checked online that Pied Piper has Christmas Eve menu so I came down to ask when it starts. I asked the server(female) when Christmas Eve menu starts but the answer I got from her was ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know‚Äù. I was stunned. I waited for other servers or manager for a couple minutes and asked the same question to a gentle man(looks like a manager, grey hair, tall in a suit) and the answer was ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know but maybe 4pm. I am going to check and let you know‚Äù. He never came back. I waited for 15 minutes and left the restaurant. 
2. Anyway I came to the Pied Piper to have Christmas Eve Menu. There were bread plates and butter knives for both of us on the table. I thought I would be served some bread since there were tablewares. A server brought the first course(salad) so I asked ‚ÄúDo you have bread? There are bread plates and butter knives but we have not served bread yet.‚Äù The answer I got was ‚ÄúYes, Do you want some bread?‚Äù. I think she should have asked before serving the first course. 
3. Pied Piper Christmas Eve Menu has 4 courses. We had 2 forks and 1 desert fork for a tableware when we started our meal. One for the first course(Salad), and the other one for the second course(Ravioli). After finishing the second course(Ravioli), the server took the plate with the fork. Later, she brought the third course(Beef short rib) without fork and we had to wait for a couple minutes to call the other server(we could not even find her) again and get the forks. (Even worse, the other server did not know where to put the fork. She put the fork right next to the knife.)
4. I finished my third course before my wife. The server came and took my plate. That‚Äôs Ok. But the thing is, she brought desert plates for my wife and me even before my wife finished the third course.
5. During our dinner, our water glasses were never filled without request. Water glasses were always empty. The worse thing was, every time I requested water, I had to ask at least two servers twice or three times. The servers do not remember(or care) what I asked for. The server even took my cup to the kitchen to refill it. 
6. After finishing our dinner, the server brought the check. There was no pen with the check. We again waited for 5 more minutes to get A PEN.< /Text>

<Gmap_id>0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb<//Gmap_id></record>
</dataset><record>
<Text>I visited while the workers' strike action was taking place, and I have several complaints to make about how the current situation was being handled by the hotel management:

1. Failure to inform arriving guests of the ongoing strike and how this affects room service and amenities, while providing the option to cancel the booking: I would have expected to be informed ahead of my stay that the strike was going on and given the opportunity to make a different choice. I went to San Francisco for the weekend to relax, but the stay was anything but relaxing given the current circumstances, and the service both at breakfast and for housekeeping as performed by substitute staff was much below the usual standard I had previously experienced.

2. Insufficient "gestures" made by hotel management to make up for inconveniences: offering a "discounted" (yet still expensive) breakfast rate during which the service was absolutely dreadful (I asked for a cappuccino three times and kept being ignored, my cell phone was removed from my table while I went to grab food, I had to repeatedly ask for cutlery as my table was set without any) and a happy hour that is not at all attractive to non-drinkers was simply not good enough. I would have at least expected to not be charged for in-room wifi as this would have been a more useful "gesture of goodwill" than anything else that had been on offer.

I would like to make clear that I empathize with the employees on strike and have been appalled by how the ongoing issue has been treated by both the Palace Hotel's management and the Marriott Group in general. Encouraging hotel guests by means of the note left in the hotel rooms to call the police department(to complain about noise levels represented another low for me and significantly lowered my respect for this hotel. I doubt that I will visit again in the near future.<//Text>< user_name>
BusinessTraveler<//user_name>

<rating>None< /rating><text>Had a great time at the Palace for a short romantic getaway.

Staff were particularly good this time. One of the maids gave us a couple of extra water bottles, and they cooperated very well one day when we were under the weather and only left the room for a little while.

We had a package coming from another Starwood property which didn't get to the Palace before we checked out. Palace staff notified us when they received the package, and forwarded it on to our home promptly.

In general, everyone was very courteous and friendly, at the front desk, bell desk, and concierge. And of course the hotel is gorgeous!</text>< pics>

<Text>My room was impeccable, the staff was super helpful and cheerful, the hotel was beautiful. <Text>Broken AC. Broken TV. Both took over and hour before an engineer could come and take a look and then over a day to fix (gave up on AC).

Was moved to a smaller room with 2 full beds as a result of room fault and not offered any apology or compensation.

If you care passionately about paying 25 dollars for a cocktail in what is admittedly a beautiful lounge - go ahead. If you actually want basic hotel service (maids who don't shout at each other in the hallways all afternoon, service that can remember to call you when food arrives or basic amenities like AC or a working television) - stay somewhere else.

Not even close to a category 6. Hotel management should be ashamed of themselves and their staff.</Text></record>

< text>
I live in San Francisco and booked this stay to celebrate my 500th night in a Starwood property. When I checked in at 2pm, the upgraded room to a junior suite was not ready and I was told I would be phoned when it was. This never happened and in the end I checked back later and it was ready at 3.30. When I asked if there was any special amenity with a 500th night, I was told I could have a bottle of red wine or a selection of local beers sent to my room. Later that day, 2 bottles of Anchor Steam were sent to my room. Making things worse, the Plt amenity of breakfast was at first not accepted in the restaurant and only after a 15 minute interruption to contact the front desk, this was granted. Service on the whole was lacking, very uncharacteristic of a Luxury Collection Hotel. In summary, a very disappointing stay and unfortunate way to celebrate my 500th night with the chain.</text>

< name>
Crocodilian<//name>
<user>None< /user>< rating>
None<//rating>
< pics>
None<//pics>
<Text>You want to like the Palace because there just aren't that many hotels like this anymore; but a recent stay shows why. Great spaces downstairs don't alter the fact that the rooms upstairs are tiny, and awkwardly constructed so that you hear every noise in the long hallways. So you get grandeur, but you give up comfort.

That's not management's fault-- barring a huge renovation, I can't see how 2014 hotel guests are going to be pleased with a lot of the rooms, which are tiny and noisy (and I suspect that they were awkwardly cut up at some point in the past from larger rooms)

What is management's problem was the long line of folks waiting to check in, while the front desk staff mysteriously did the full "let me orient you to the hotel and San Francisco" for each guest. They spent five minutes and more per check in, a process that can be done in sixty seconds (if the reservation is correct)-- exceptionally irritating as folks waited 45 minutes to check in.

So a suggestion to check in staff: if there's a long line of folks waiting to check in, get it done as fast as possible. You have a concierge desk that can help people if they have questions about the restaurant or the hotel; check in staff doesn't have to play tour guide when a long line of folks is waiting. I think management assumes that this is part of a "welcoming experience" -- but mostly it irritates the folks who're hoping to get to their room after a long trip.

Recommendation: the hotel's facilities have character that you can't duplicate today, the Pied Piper Bar is a step back into history, the fast disappearing world of American mid-century. But I'd much rather stay nearby at two other properties in the Starwood portfolio, the Westin or the St Regis, and have a drink at the Palace . . .</Text>< Response>
None< /Response>
</record>

<rate>None< /rate>< review>
The only positive things I can say about the Palace Hotel are the location and its historical nature and the lobby decor. However, as a hotel that's supposed to be a luxury hotel, it falls way below the mark!! The front desk staff was atrocious. I waited 10 minutes in line, then some person just walked up to the front desk out of nowhere, as it was my turn; and the staff member went ahead and helped her and not me!! No apologies. Nothing. What's up with that?! Then, my room had a great view of a wall of the next building! The room was in need of repair with peeling paint, dirty floors. Housekeeping did not clean the bathroom daily. There was no turndown service (I admit, a frivolity, but with the high room rate and the supposed quality of the hotel, I would have expected it). The pool and fitness center were run down. I could have had better service at a lesser "quality" hotel.< /review>

We had not stayed at The Palace when visiting SF for a few years and were very happy with the cleanliness and care given to this beautiful building. The Front Desk welcome was great, housekeeping was friendly and helpful, as was the bell staff and garage. The only glitch was a breakfast experience in The Garden Court one morning. The eggs over medium came cooked to death (wife ate them). It was just really, really unprofessional and off-putting. THAT entire situation can be improved upon. LOVELY hotel otherwise.<//review>

<user>107433150273567804942< /user><name>Dane Jacobson<//name><date>1490060234671< /date><Rating>4<//Rating>< Text>
A pretty standard hotel in the SPG Luxury Collection (which is a good thing). We only stayed one night but were treated to the customary excellent service I would expect for a "4-star" SPG property. The rooms are on the small side, but that's normal for downtown SF. A little surprising is the lack of coffee makers in-room, though apparently you can call the (very responsive) front desk and have one brought to your room. There is free coffee for guests in the lobby from 6am to 10am, which is a slightly narrow window. The design and ornamentation feels quite high end without being outright gaudy as you might see in some more expensive hotels. The location is superb.<//Text>

<userid>None< /userid>< Review>
Overall, a good stay although it fell short of my expectation in terms of room amenities for a hotel that is part of the luxury collection. Basic amenities such as bedroom slippers and coffee/tea making facilities are just some of the items that the room was lacking. The bathroom was small and didn't quite have sufficient tabletop space or hanging spots. There was only a small window with insufficient sunlight coming through and the room didn't have enough lighting. Definitely not conducive for business travelers who may need to conduct business work in the room. Having said all the above, the bed was very comfortable and I felt well rested. In summary, there is a sense of grandeur in the common areas of the hotel; however, it didn't feel quite the same when it came to the room.< /Review>

110094179755524981422</userid>
<username>Dave Keil</username><Time>1540948551765<//Time><rate>2</rate>< Text>
At or near the worst hotel I've stayed in.

I came up to my room after i checked in and discovered the beding was down.  Being super alergic to feathers i needed to have them changed.  It took two calls to housekeeping before they came, and had me leave the room only to just dump some ikea pillows and fleece blankets at the foot of the untouched bed.  I took all the feather stuff off and stuffed the bedding in the corner.  The next day my bed was remade with all the bedding in the room, and i had to call twice again to get it changed and specifically asked to have the down bedding removed.

The remade bedding was colder then what was left last night, and the thermoatat only goes to 75F.  I woke up at 4am shiverring, unable to sleep from them, and called down to the front desk to get it set higher and a space heater brought up.  A guy from engineering turned up and explained the thermostat is locked that way, and all he could do was disable the cold water to the AC.  He found me a space heater.

After two horrible nights sleep I'm at least not freezing, but the down remnants left it the sheets makes for an itchy sleep.</Text>

<Rate>None<//Rate><Response>None< /Response>< text>
Sorry to say it, I stayed in most of the SPG properties in the San Francisco area with most comfortable sleep, unfortunately at Palace I lost my sleep due to auto shutoff of Air Conditioners, I'm sure other customers might have similar experience. The problem is in the location of censors on Doors in an L shaped room, where movements on Bed are not recognized by censors on the door. I have to get up in the middle of sleep and wave my hands towards the doors for Air Conditioner to work again.

I raised this as a concern was given a different room but it is still same kind of room. I didn't expected this from a great hotel like this, the other issue I faced was Television Power line was unplugged.

Please relook at the location of censors on the property, the least a business person on travel expects a good night sleep after hectic travel and work.</text>

< review>
Upon check in, I had to push the receptionist to recognize my platinum benefits and give me the complimentary breakfast. What a mistake it was to get the breakfast benefit -- the staff treated me like I was a huge bother and did not refill our drinks once. 

Beyond that, the rooms are not designed for any sort of business travel as there is no in room coffee maker. 

Really disappointed as this is a nice property. Outside of the very few gems, the staff is bad.</review>

<user>None< /user><username>Renee63< /username>< time>
1384214400000</time>
<Rating>None</Rating>< Text>
Check in took a long time as systems were not responsive. Reception desk had to go to three different computer systems before check in could be accomplished. Not a big deal on its own but when all of the other problems followed next, then it was just one of a number.
Next morning I ordered coffee and a banana. For $13, I got coffee, no banana. They brought it later but I had to go. I left the room to return in the afternoon to a less than presentable "refreshed room". The iron and ironing board was still out in the room with a room robe wadded up on it, trash not emptied, dirty napkins left on the desk where coffee was and refuse on the bedside table. No toilet tissue replenished. Basically, the bed had been made and the coffee dishes were removed but that is all. Overall, for the price paid, the experience was less than stellar, and I do not think I could recommend this hotel. After providing this info on a comment card upon check out, I am stunned that there has been no attempt to connect with me about it by a member of hotel management. Rarely do I take the time to comment but this time it was necessary.< /Text>

< Review>
I travel a great deal with my work. Unfortunately from my check in, through my departure, I felt as if I was a bother to the staff, rather than a guest. As an example, my check-in took 3 times as long as another staff member. (Perhaps the gentleman was new -- but I stood by and watched 3 other guests move through the process while I waited for him to check me in.) When asking for a late check out, I was brushed aside by the staff member at the front desk. I have stayed in other Starwood hotels and have enjoyed the experience. This one -- not so much.</Review>

<Pics>None<//Pics>< name>
COF613</name>
<Review>As an SPG member, I opted to use my Suite Night Awards to request a suite for my stay. I received an email from SPG prior to my stay advising that they would not be able to accommodate my request - ok, no big deal. Except a day later I get an email from the Palace Hotel advising that I can pay to uprgade to a suite. Hmm...so they are available...you just want more money? Got it. Needless to say I found that to be a little sneaky on their part, and a well run organization should not need to pull stunts like that just to make a few extra bucks.

When we arrived, I immediately thought the hotel was breathtaking. The garden eating area was absolutely stunning and we enjoyed a great meal there. Then...we got up to our room. Now coming from a tiny apartment in NYC, my expectations for hotel rooms are not that high - I just want them to be nicer than my apartment...not a difficult task. The room was an outdated closet. The bathroom looked like it had not been updated since the hotel opened, the bedroom was so tiny it could really only fit a bed and two side tables - why they decided to shove a chair and footrest in there is beyond me. Overall, just - ugh. My husband and I were both very disappointed.

On the bright side - we only stayed for 2 nights, then were off to another Starwood hotel that exceeded our expectations! :)<//Review><gmapID>0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb< /gmapID>< Rate>

<Text>I am not sure what has happened to this hotel over he years. The lower level staff, maids, bellman, parking attendants are all very good, nice and polite, but the senior staff, front desk etc. seem to constantly be smirking; like they are in on an inside joke; it's funny to charge $60 a day to park, or sending a guest to a room that is not made up yet, knowing the gym is a joke, or making just plain useless concierge recommendations. < username>

<time>1435104000000< /time><Rate>None<//Rate>< Text>
I had looked up tripadvisor reviews and was surprised at the ranking the palace had. After staying there this weekend I can see why it is ranked so low for a 4 star luxury property that recently has been upgraded to category 6. First off, spg has recently decided to offer Internet for free to spg members who book directly. I had done that so I called to ask about how to go about receiving this. The guest services operator had no idea about this and stated it was only for certain spg levels. She forwarded me to the front desk, no response. Asked for them to call me back, no calls. Decided to reach out to social media team but the reception was so poor I couldn't use my phone. Eventually finally was verified by the Twitter team that I was correct. Tried again asking about internet but nothing. Finally spoke to Casey(or kc) and he ackowledged I was correct and that I could go ahead and state I was going to pay for Internet access when prompted and he would note my account to remove the charges. Next morning I receive an email from terry apologizing and offering free Internet as a courtesy gesture. Well Casey already did that so I wrote back, which I never received a reply. Being ignored is not fun.

Oh one more thing, Door view finder was blocked, stuffed with tissue paper! Who does that? Tweeted a picture to palace, of course they didn't reply until the day after check out.</Text>

< Rate>

<Text>We love the Garden Court restaurant and during our frequent stays in SF it is one of our favorite place to have business breakfast. Based on this, we decided to book our hotel room at the Palace Hotel for 2 nights during the 2013 holidays season. Actually we have been disappointed because we were expecting much more about the comfort. This hotel is very noisy, not cosy at all, and security control is pretty nonexistent. We arrived very late (1:30 am) but got waked up at 7:00 am when young kids started to run and scream in the hallways. We thought we had to take advantage of this early wake up to get breakfast at our favorite place. Second deception: the Garden Court turned down our demand for a table of 2 because he told us there was no table available (2/3 of the restaurant was empty!), so we had to get to an hotel manager to finally have our breakfast. Thanks to her.
I think we will go back to our usual plan for next time: having a room in another hotel much more comfortable where we have a better status, and come at the Garden Court restaurant only for breakfast or brunch.</Text>< pictures>

<userid>108527869489702213865< /userid><user_name>Jim Augerinos</user_name>< Time>
1474098652895<//Time>
< Rating>
3</Rating>
< Review>
Not sure what's thinner the walls(when I hear my neighbor shower, break wind, flush the toilet, sneeze) or the window pane from 1875 that allows me to hear every conversation from passersbys) but my sanctuary from all that is the water closet....

When I am able to fit myself in the the water closet(it takes time and skill honed over 3 blissful nights in the sarcophagus of what is considered a room here at the palace) I find my happy place, free from the nuisance of technology, space(although I can shower and sit on the commode at the same time) car horns, heels from the damsels below ,steam whistles, burbling furnaces, historic copper pipes playing the songs of Harpies, Lament's of the homeless gentleman with the whole foods shopping cart and niners jersey below, those are from which I draw my inspiration after countless sleepless nights to write this fable of my incarnation.... I mean visitation to  this grand old Dame of what masquerades as a luxury collection hotel.......<//Review>

<userid>None<//userid><Name>SBarbara< /Name><Time>1357171200000<//Time>< rate>
None<//rate>
< review>
Had a wonderful stay at the Palace and it was centrally located to what we wanted to do. We were able to walk to China Town, the Emabrcadero and Union Square .There is public transportation right outside the door for Fisherman's Wharf as well as other areas served by BART. The doorman was attentive to our needs for quick transportation whenever we needed a cab and he even arranged for a limo on New Year's Eve to take us to our restaurant.. The concierge was helpful in directions to places to eat and for getting around the city. My only problem was with the front desk/housekeeping. Granted it was New Years Eve afternoon and I know the staff was busy getting ready for the hotel's big New Years Eve party but it took over 6 hours and several calls to get extra glasses delivered and to replace the wet bathrobe that had been on the floor since early in the morning when we left the hotel for the day's activities. I called the front desk at 5:15 to request extra glasses since we were expecting another registered couple to our room later that night for drinks as well as a replacement for the bathrobe that housekeeping forgot in the morning when our room was cleaned up. We called again when we retuned to the room at 11:00 pm since these items had still not been delivered. The front desk was apologetic and we had our glasses and bathrobe delivered with a smile and an apology within 30 minutes. I would definitely stay here again!</review>

<review>This was our first stay, and will be our last. For the class of hotel The Palace is, it falls short. The room was fine, and the bed comfortable, but the carpet was old and stained, and they couldn't get the WiFi signal strength to a decent level. < Review>
This was not my first preference but I was in town for a conference and this was the organization's hotel of choice. The hotel is certainly gorgeous and the facility has great meeting rooms. While the stay overall was satisfactory, there were several issues I feel compelled to share. There is a fee for Internet service. Granted, there are still hotels that charge for this. However, it was impossible to access most of the time and I ended up using most of my data plan on my cel phone for Internet. I did speak to technical support on 6 different occasions during my stay in an attempt to get it to work consistently. Finally gave up.

Towards the end of my 6 night stay, I awoke in the middle of the night to use the bathroom, only to discover that housekeeping had not left a replacement roll of bathroom tissue when they cleaned the room. Another major inconvenience at 3am.

Once I arrived home, I realized that the folio I was given only covered 1 night of my stay. Now dealing with trying to get a copy of it from the Accounting department. Left them a message and hoping to hear back.

None of these inconveniences are that big a deal, but together they detract greatly from what might have been a great experience.</Review>

1436486400000< /Time>
< review>
I booked a room at the Palace Hotel for a very special weekend. I had planned a surprise engagement for my girlfriend and flew her parents into San Francisco to take part in the surprise. While I had other less expensive options in San Francisco, I chose the Palace Hotel because it is a part of Starwood‚Äôs Luxury Collection and I wanted to treat my future in-laws to something special. Unfortunately, Palace Hotel experience was everything but special.

Being a Starwood Gold Member, I requested an early check-in. This request was not only denied but my future mother-in-law was not even able to check in at the guaranteed 3PM check in time and had to change in the bathroom to prepare for the evening‚Äôs festivities. When she returned to the hotel in high spirits after a wonderful evening, she was disappointed with complexity of checking in at 11PM. Not only that, but the staff was unable to retrieve her checked in luggage so she had to walk into the luggage closet to find and pick up her luggage herself. This is a very frustrating experience to top off a long day and evening.

The next morning, the request for late check out was again denied even after explaining the situation from the previous night. To make matters worse, the staff was reluctant to check their luggage back in as they claimed to be too ‚Äúbusy‚Äù at the time.

This is NOT the experience I would expect from a Starwood hotel, not to mention any hotel that charges $400-$500 a night.

Disappointed by this entire experience, I left the management at Palace a message the following week only to be met with silence for over a week. Only after placing a formal complaint with Startwood customer service, did I receive a generic email from The Palace front desk manager acknowledging the complaint. No apology was made and no offers to make things right other than sentence stating that my next stay with them will be ‚Äúflawless‚Äù.

It‚Äôs hard to believe that Starwood would even let hotels with such bad service carry their name. To say the least, I extremely disappointed and am rethinking my loyalty to Starwood as a whole.<//review>

I do not consider myself a "travel warrior" but have traveled a fair amount or both business and pleasure. For me the "value" of the accommodation just was not there. Maybe $650.night is considered a "deal" in SF but never-the-less there is an expectation when you are being charged this much. The marked and gouged furniture, tattered lampshades, non-operating light, cracked bathroom basin and un cleaned vanity top were definitely not what I expected. <Rate>None</Rate><Text>This is supposed to be a four star "luxury" hotel. Check in took a while. The "SPG" line had a clerk who was on the phone and not checking in guests. The other clerk had a guest who was checked in but was being chatty. The clerk saw us in line, but made no effort to end the conversation with the other guest. So, we waited. The room was a gorgeous junior suite. The bathroom faucet was dripping. We had co-workers over that night for cheese and wine, so we ordered wine glasses up to the room. The next morning, we found out the bathtub wasn't draining very well, so we were ankle deep in soapy water during our showers. Upon leaving for our business meeting, I told the front desk of the dripping faucet, the slow draining tub and could we please have more towels. Upon arriving back at the room later that afternoon, the sink was still dripping and there was a stack of towels on the sofa. The dirty wine glasses were still on the coffee table and the dirty hand towels in the bathroom hadn't been replaced or even straightened. The next morning, we noticed that the tub was draining nicely. Upon checkout, we told the clerk about our experience. "We are so sorry" was said, but that was it.</Text><Pics>None<//Pics><Resp>None</Resp><gmapID>0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb</gmapID></record></dataset><record>

<rate>None<//rate><Review>This hotel does not compare to other spg properties such as those in Europe. The room was adequate and for a spg property I would have at least expected slippers in the room. The food, however, exceeded expectations and service was excellent and friendly.<//Review><Pics>None< /Pics>< resp>
None< /resp>
< gmapID>
0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb<//gmapID>
</record></dataset><record>
< Text>
We reserved a room with two beds. The terms of that reservation were carefully specified in the original reservation and then reconfirmed by phone. Upon arrival, a front desk staffer suggested that we take a king bed with two rollaways. Upon seeing the room, it was a ridiculous suggestion. We literally had to walk across beds to move from one part of the room to another. It turned out that the front desk staffer urged us to take that type of room because the type we had reserved was already fully subscribed. In other words, the hotel did not in practice hold the specified type of room for us, then tried to pass off an unsuitable room as better. The hotel then discounted the room and offered to switch us to a two-bed room for the balance of the stay. However, the hotel was not able to effect that switch until 5 pm the following day, leading to another full day of inconvenience. The Palace in SF did not fulfill the terms of the reservation, did not deal with us transparently, and delivered less than what was reserved. Reservations at the hotel are not to be taken at face value. Confirm what you have specified in your reservation in advance, get the details of who confirms it, and hold the front desk staff to the terms of the reservation. I have had a much better experience at other, nominally lesser Starwood properties than what I received at the Palace. I would not recommend it.</Text>

<user_name>Aatnaples< /user_name><time>1398988800000<//time><Rating>None</Rating>< review>
The Palace has long been one of my favorite hotels in San Francisco. It's storied past, exquisite public spaces, the Pied Piper Bar are all traditions not to be missed. But a recent visit showed that the luster has faded. The carpets in the hallways and rooms are in need of replacement. The walls in the common areas and rooms were marked up and the staff seemed less than entusiastic. I have stayed here many times before, but I must admit I probably will not return unless there are some iimprovements made. Room service trays sat for hours in the hallways, the gym was unattended and the lockers were not available for use, and the staff at the Front Desk was abrupt at check in.< /review>

< name>
Stephen49< /name>
< user>
None< /user>
< response>
None< /response>
</record></dataset><record>
<userid>None</userid><username>CTraveler< /username>< date>
1407369600000<//date>
<rating>None<//rating>< Review>
I have stayed at this hotel many times, and in general it's a lovely place, right in the heart of downtown San Francisco. This time I booked on points. Since I will be a Lifetime Platinum this year, I know what to expect for service at a Luxury Collection Starwood Hotel. That's not what I got on this trip. I got to the front desk around 2:15 pm, but the room wasn't ready yet, which was fine. After confirmation of my phone number the desk clerk said he'd phone me when the room was ready. At 5 pm I still had not received a call, and was due at a dinner engagement at 6, so I went back to the hotel to find out what was going on. The desk clerk told me that they only call if the room becomes available before the standard 3 pm check in time. Supposedly the room became available at the standard check in time, so no one bothered to call. This put me in a bind for meeting my dinner engagement. The clerk got me into the room quickly, but then the luggage valet brought someone else's luggage and had to go back to get mine. The clerk also sent a note with chocolate and wine as an apology, which I appreciated. Upon return from dinner I discovered that there was no remote control in my room for the TV. I called, and half an hour later, still no remote. Called AGAIN, and finally it showed up, more than 45 minutes after my initial call. The room needed maintenance - the overhead light in the bath flickered constantly, and the shower drain was so slow that I was up to my ankles in water by the end of the shower. The next day I asked the front desk for a shopping bag, and was told the hotel did not offer them. I happen to know this is untrue, since they are usually in the closet. The clerk called housekeeping and learned they were available. I was told one would be sent to my room right away. I delayed leaving the hotel for the day to wait for it but, 45 minutes later, still no shopping bag, so I left. The shopping bag was there upon my return 4 hours later.
Also, be aware that the Platinum complimentary breakfast is for CONTINENTAL only. I put a spoonful of eggs on my plate and got charged $7.00 for that.
This is a beautiful property and a Luxury level hotel in the Starwood group should be doing much better than this on the small details. All this wouldn't prevent me from coming back, but it sure doesn't help the hotel stand out.</Review>
< pictures>
None</pictures>
< response>
None</response>

<resp>None</resp><username>OnTheRoadAgain2013<//username>< Pics>

<date>1385078400000< /date>< review>
I was extremely disappointed in this hotel. The walls between rooms are paper thin. You can hear everything that is going on in the rooms next to you. And it's not your neighbors being loud, it's just them talking in a normal voice.

I talked to the front desk staff about moving my room after the first night of this, but according to the person I spoke with all the rooms are the same when it comes to that. Seems like they hear that issue a lot. It's just really weird, they do a great job of keeping out the street noise. But they can't put insulation between the rooms.

They also need to do something about the constant slamming of doors. Seriously this is a luxury brand hotel. How about some luxury then.

The bed was great. Bathroom was tiny. No space to put our toiletries. Great location. Great breakfast.</review>

Simon Chang< /user_name>
< text>
Had breakfast buffet, great environment, food's pretty good, but could use a greater selection for the price</text>
<user>109712112729186842324<//user><resp>None< /resp><Gmap_id>0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb< /Gmap_id><Time>1533936874930< /Time></record></dataset><record>
<Gmap_id>0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb< /Gmap_id><Date>1358467200000</Date><UserId.>None< /UserId.><Response>None<//Response>< Pictures>
None</Pictures>
< Review>
We stayed for 2 nights at the end of December. Staying here is a treat to appreciate the history of the hotel and the city. In addition to the ornate details and beautiful building it was nice to see the hotel decorated and lighted for the Christmas holidays.

As others have said the bathrooms are a bit on the small side but they are nonetheless nicely appointed. I did not miss not having a coffee maker in the room and had no problem going down to the beautiful lobby in the morning to get my coffee fix (I‚Äôm sure the quality of the coffee from the lobby is far superior to anything you would get from an in-room coffee maker anyway.) Since the price of breakfast for two of us would have probably cost around $50 we opted to eat breakfast at a bakery/coffee shop around the corner on Market Street.

When we checked in I asked for a room away from the elevators only to be assigned to room 660 directly next to the elevator! We tried the room for about an hour but could hear the elevators running in the room plus we got a lot of noise from other guests talking loudly while waiting for the elevators. After an hour I decided this would not be a satisfactory room for our stay. After twice trying to call the front desk to enquire about moving to a different room and no one picking up, I walked down to the front desk. The desk was not busy so I‚Äôm not sure why they never picked up the phone when I called. I explained our room dissatisfaction to the same clerk that checked us in and she was able to find us a room on the 8th floor away from the elevators.

The high ceilings in the rooms make them feel spacious and the beds are very comfortable. Between the two rooms we used, one had a large closet and the other had a wardrobe. The view from our room was across to another part of the hotel and looking up you could see the top of the hotel sign on the roof facing Market Street. Since we were in an interior room we did not have any street noise. But the walls are rather thin so we could hear people talking and the TV from the room next to ours.

On our second night we had some drinks and dessert in the Pied Piper Bar. It was amazing to have drinks in a room with a $2 million dollar painting but the service was a bit slow.

Overall we think it‚Äôs a beautiful hotel and we would probably stay there again even with some of the minor complaints I‚Äôve listed above. (If you‚Äôre at the hotel on a Tuesday, Thursday, or Saturday you can take a 90 minute historic tour of the hotel that departs from close to the concierge desk.)

TIP: Due to the beautiful open stairways and open area by the elevators, the acoustics tend to amplify the voices of people waiting for elevators; if this would be bothersome to you, ask for a room away from the elevators</Review>
<user_name>Dizknee< /user_name><rating>None< /rating></record>
</dataset><record>

<Rating>None< /Rating>< Name>
waiakea< /Name>

1488153600000</Time>
<userid>None</userid><Pictures>None</Pictures></record></dataset><record>
<user>115500908801043886843<//user>< username>
Megan Harvell<//username>
<time>1442175544660</time>< Rate>
2<//Rate>
< Review>
The two stars for this place only come from the beauty of the architecture in the main lobby.

When we arrived, the only (and very rude) concierge was assisting other guests at the time. Did not mind the wait, but was curious as to why one of the many other employees milling about the lobby could not also be assisting guests at the front desk.

There seemed to be a misunderstanding about pricing that the other guests were concerned about. They were repeatedly talked down to as the concierge ("Shan", on his name plate) insisted he was right about the price, bringing out a calculator, and loudly discussing the matter in front of us and another party waiting in line.

After those guests were finished with their transaction, we approached the same frazzled concierge. He apologized for the wait, unnecessarily adding, "So frustrating..." in regard to what had just transpired with the previous guests. He then hurriedly checked us in without many pleasantries, and did not inform us about any amenities for our use beyond the time the pool and fitness area closed.

The next day, as we did not have time to enjoy the pool but wanted to see it, we asked two managers in the lobby what floor we could find the pool on. One manager was uncertain and consulted another. They both agreed it was on floor 3 and to take a left from the elevators. It was on floor four, we found out, after trying to navigate the third to no avail. Frustrating that the managers of a hotel as beautiful as this would not know this information.

Our room was very nice albeit smaller than imagined. However, the stunning view of a courtyard that looks out only onto a rooftop and other rooms all facing inward on each other, was enough to keep the curtains drawn and leave unimpressed.

Would not recommend to friends.< /Review>

<UserId.>105806848314874253215< /UserId.><Name>Evan P</Name>< Date>
1528041160655< /Date>
< Rating>
4<//Rating>
<Review>The Palace Hotel is a good luxury hotel with a great location in the heart of San Francisco.

The Hotel: The Palace hotel is a beautiful hotel with a wonderful sitting/brunch area. Wonderful stained glass windows and beautiful pillars adorn the lobby making this hotel feel like a luxury hotel. The pool and workout facilities are great but can be very loud if children are present, I wouldn't say that this is a relaxing hotel but more of a good hotel to explore SF from. The rooms have very high ceilings and were spacious and reflect what I would expect from a 4-star hotel. Our window view was facing toward the inside so we had a view of all the other inside windows, but this meant that we had no street noise and our room was very quiet. The walls are not 100% sound proof and I was woken up one night by, what I am assuming to be, a bachelorette party which was creating a considerable amount of noise screaming and yelling at 2am. Thankfully they left, but I wouldn't expect complete sonic isolation in your hotel room.  Hotel staff were helpful and the concierge was phenomenally good and I would highly recommend Debbie.

The Location: This hotel is located on prime real estate and is within walking distance (15 min walk) of the Embarcadero. My family and I had no trouble getting an Uber to take us to Fisherman's Wharf in under 10 mins. It is also on Market street, which is a large public transportation hub, is very close to union square (where all the tour buses pick up), and is very close to the SF Museum of Modern Art! My only gripe with the location is lack of parking, we paid over $35/day to park our rental car in a hidden parking garage, and there is a very large homeless population that is around the hotel. The hotel staff do a great job of keeping the homeless population out of the hotel and off the property, but as soon as you walk anywhere else away from the hotel there are a significant number of homeless people. I felt somewhat safe walking back to the hotel at night but I would recommend taking an Uber/Taxi straight to the hotel entrance instead.

Overall this hotel is definitely what I have come to expect from a city based 4-Star hotel and I was satisfied with my experience. Good location and good rooms provided an overall good experience.<//Review>< pics>
None<//pics>

< GmapID>
0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb<//GmapID>
<user>None< /user>< text>
The Palace is a San Francisco Classic with a historically high reputation. It's designation as a Starwood, Luxuary Collection Property adds to one's expectations. While many of the property's features meet these high expectations, sadly the property is more than a little worn around the edges.
The Garden Room is beautiful, but service there is lacking, inconsistant, limited, and over priced for what it is now.
The front lobby is almost non-existent, though staff were friendly and professional. A grand hotel needs a lobby.
Low spot was guest room. Bedrooms were in desperate need of renovation; dirty worn carpet and upholstery, broken unfinished furniture and inaccessible electrical outlets. On the positive side; comfortable bed and good shower! saved the day. Walls are paper thin, lots of noise between rooms and the hallway. Loud drunk young people had to be removed from hallway at 3 am. Please renovate these rooms, or don't rent them as Starwood luxury collection!
Maxwell's Pied Piper Bar and Grill is a high point. It does exude classic San Francisco, comfortable, warm and friendly, ..‚Ä¶.but even here service was slow, and bar food menu limited.
The Palace remains a classic San Francisco landmark, and I hope that it receives the attention that it desperately needs.<//text>

< text>
This was our first and last time staying at The Palace.
Prior to our arrival I requested an earlier check in time, as a SPG member this request is usually granted. We arrived at 11:15AM, checked in and was told our room wasn't ready, understandable.
I was told someone will call when the room is ready. After shopping for about 3 hrs we head back to the hotel, only to be told the room is still not ready. Really? The front desk staff didn't even to offer to call housekeeping to find out when it would be ready, he just stated that Check in is at 3PM, it should be ready by then. Really? That's SPG Service? It's not and it is the reason why I will not go back to this hotel when visiting San Francisco.
Valet parking is super expensive and super slow, it took over 35 minutes to retrieve our car, we were told it would only take 15. Oh, one more thing, it was never acknowledged that I was a SPG member, and to top it off, they write down the room rate you paid on the back of the key holder, tackiest thing I've ever experienced at a hotel. I asked why they did that and the response was "it's our policy so people know how much they are paying for the room." HUH?

Spoke to a manager, she was very apologetic and understanding. She tried to do right, I accepted her offer. But learned a few things as to why the hotel is dysfunctional. Bottom line, it's San Francisco and there are many other properties to choose from. Enjoy the aesthetics, but stay somewhere else.<//text>

<review>With checkin listed as 3pm, I arrived at 2:50 and was told my room was not ready but I would be called on my mobile as soon as it was ready. After sitting in the lobby for over 2 hrs waiting for a call I re-approached the front desk. Reuben, who originally checked me in, lied and said he called my mobile and left a message. I then was issued a handicap room. Upon discovering that I requested a regular room. Reuben said he would send the bellman with keys immediately. After 10 minutes and no bellman I returned to the front desk to collect the new keys myself. Again Reuben lied that a bellman was waiting for me. I then asked to speak to a manager. Reuben said a manager would call me. Unsurprisingly, I never received any contact from anyone else. The delayed checkin made me late for my dinner meeting and soured my overall stay.< /review>< pics>

<UserId.>None<//UserId.><username>ManuN< /username>< time>
1345939200000<//time>
< Rating>
None</Rating>
< text>
Ultimately, The Palace Hotel did not live up to our expectations. The common areas of the hotel are absolutely gorgeous and I would encourage anyone looking for a high end brunch to visit the hotel on a weekend for brunch. That said, the guest rooms were drab. They showed significant signs of aging with peeling paint and splintered doors and were very poorly decorated. Additionally, the walls in the hotel are paper thin. We were greeted each morning to the alarm of one of our neighbors (just a standard blackberry alarm) and we could hear the woman on the other side whenever she was on the phone. And even though we were at the end of the hall, not near the elevator, we heard noise from the hallways whenever people were coming or going to their rooms. I definitely would not stay at this hotel again.< /text>

< text>
My husband and I had our wedding reception here 17 years ago and wanted to return for a romantic evening. The hotel itself is beautiful and quiet, in the lobby and main areas. However, we were awakened by the cries of a screaming toddler at 7 a.m. on a Sunday morning. After that the maids were banging on doors yelling, "Housekeeping!" even though ours had a "Do not disturb" sign. After that stopped, it sounded like someone was moving in at about 8:30 a.m. Turns out they were moving all of the beds out of the rooms. The thought of bed bugs and "The Shining" simultaneously crossed my mind. I wonder if we would have had better luck with noise if we just stayed in the lobby?<//text>

<review>This stay was to make good on the hotel falling short for our Wedding in January 2014. This was a offer to redo our stay for our honeymoon as the staff member for our wedding put us in a different room of lesser looks after sending us photos of a nicer suite saying we would be staying there.
Now I go in May to book the room for us that night of June 9-10. The woman does not send me to the manager that told me to book with him, finds out I am using a gift certificate and tells me its completely booked. NOT until I go online and explain I have in holding a reservation for our room we were supposed to have that she books it for us. ALREADY that leaves a bad taste in my mouth.
We arrive. we get undressed and head to the pool to take a jacuzzi. Not a sign saying anything, yet the jacuzzi is empty. Ridiculous. So we decide on getting a facial in the spa.. only to wonder for 45 min until a guest explains there is no spa anymore... TAKE DOWN THE SIGN for a spa if you do not have a spa in the hotel.
We then sadly go back to our room and decide to use the jacuzzi. I call downstairs because there is powder all over the inside of the tub. Concerned I ask what it could be and she just says "it may be cleanser, just rinse it out and itll be fine." Am I a maid? Do I do that at my own home? NO. <pics>None</pics><name>Aron Galonsky</name><Review>I really wanted to like the Palace Hotel.  I stayed there as part of a vacation in SF.  Note, I stay in SF probably 10-12 times a year on business, and average 20-30 stays in hotels a year.

In any event, as part of the Starwood Luxury collection, I was expecting, well, luxury.  Instead I was treated a bit rudely by the staff checking us in.  The room we had was smallish, and if it was renovated, not in many years.  We had arrived at the hotel around 10:30 am, early for a 3 pm check in. I didn't expect to get in then, but was hoping we could get a room by 1 pm or so, so that we could wash up to head out with friends.  Again, even with my Platinum status, I never felt entitled to a room before 3 pm, but was disappointed.  At 4 pm when I tried to check in, I was told my room was still not ready, and they didn't know when it would be.  That's when, I admit, I got frustrated.  In any event, after a conversation we received our downgraded room.

I'll spare the rest of the complaints, but suffice to say you're better off at the Westin St. Francis at a similar price point, a great restaurant in the hotel, and always friendly service.< /Review><date>1367715143206< /date><response>None</response><rating>2< /rating></record>
</dataset><record>

The roll away bed could sleep only one person. We won't be visiting this place again.</Review>

<name>ParisPlatinum</name>< Date>
1400371200000<//Date>
<Rate>None<//Rate>< Text>
My wife and I stayed at the Palace Hotel this past week end. This was probably my poorest experience at a Starwoods property ever. As a frequent traveler, details matter to me and there was clearly no attention to detail in this property:
- we arrived at 3:30pm to check in. The front desk lady told us that our room was being finished up and was not immediately ready. She offered a temporary room while ours was being finished. We agreed and told her we wanted to take a shower and she said it was fine and probably by the time we finished our shower, our main room would be ready. She took my cell phone number and said she would call once the room was ready. An hour past and no call! I called the front desk and someone picked up and said they would check and call me back. After about 10 minutes, I called again. This time, they finally did call me back and said the room was ready at last. A manager came to our temporary room and brought us the key. She said they had not called because she had been told by the front desk lady that we had gone out for a few hours and would return later!
- I called to ask if we could get a couple toothbrush amenity kits and shampoo. After about ten minutes, someone came to our room with just one toothbrush amenity kit and no shampoo. We had to call again...
- I called to ask where the mini bar prices were and the person on the phone could not answer me. She said it might be on the TV if I go through the menu items...
- During that same call, I asked if there were any olatinum lounges at the hotel. She had no idea what I was talking about and told me about the bar and the restaurant
- Sunday morning, we called to ask for an additional coffee capsule for the coffee machine we had in our room. At first the person on the phone did not get it and asked twice if we want a coffee machine! Finally when she got it, she said she would send us a capsule. After waiting 30 minutes, we gave up and left the hotel. We checked out earlier than we had initially planned for

No single incident was a red flag in its own but the accumulation of them made our experience very poor. We had much greater expectations from such a property in the Starwoods portfolio.</Text>
