<Response>None<//Response><Date>1582838885760</Date>< username>
Mark<//username>
</record></dataset><record>
< Time>
1343260800000<//Time>
<pictures>None<//pictures><Text>I was looking for a centrally located hotel in San Francisco that was a Starwoods property and had a pool. The Palace was the only hotel I found that met my requirements. The W does not have a pool.

The hotel is located in the business district. The pool is nice and my kids had a good time going swimming. The staff was friendly and helpful.

However, there is NO free internet in the rooms - you have to go to the lobby to get free internet. These days, it is unacceptable to make you pay for internet in your room. Also, I had to pay $60.00 a day to park my car, which was also ridiculous.

The room we had was nice but on the small side - smaller than the other Starwood properties we had stayed at. However, that was not what bothered me about the hotel. The rooms were not properly cleaned. I found a used and dirty q-tip on the bathroom floor along with a half eaten ice cream in the freezer. Also, a careful inspection around the bed (which I always do to check for you know what) showed that it wasn't too clean and I found an M&M on the floor.

While you may not expect a hotel room to be spotless, a used and dirty q-tip in the bathroom was plain disgusting.</Text><Response>None< /Response><user_name>PBTraveler<//user_name><rating>None<//rating><gmapID>0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb< /gmapID><user_id>None<//user_id></record>
</dataset><record>

< text>
We've been staying at the Palace for years - usually come up at least 2 times a year and stay there - until this recent experience....

After taking a shower on Friday night, the tub filled up with water and wouldn't drain. I called down to the front desk after the shower and asked that they have engineering come up the next day to unplug the drain as standing in dirty soapy water seemed like it was the most hygienic experience....they assured me that they would have someone come the next morning.

We spent my birthday out in the city and didn't come back to the hotel until later that evening....entered the shower around midnight and the exact same thing happened. I called the manager on duty and he asked if they could come fix the problem - we'd already showered and were going to bed to leave the next morning!

I'll never spend my birthday weekend there again!< /text>

<review>Incredibly elegant hotel. Looking forward to returning. Book room with valet included and save. Otherwuse valet I believe is $75 per night.

I was there just before Christmas and the decorations were right out of a movie. There is a never-ending list of pluses. Restaurant and bar in hotel. A bit pricey but good. Room service is incredibly fast. Just like their wi-fi internet.

Montgomery BART station is immediately outside hotel. Walk out via Ghirardelli store exit and two steps later you are walking down into BART.

It's an older hotel so rooms are smaller than newer hotels. But quite comfortable.< /review><name>p ablo</name>< rate>

< Review>
#1. The biggest problem for me was discovering in the morning that the door to the adjoining room not only wasn't locked, it wouldn't even latch. That totally creeped me out.
#2. The air fan started and stopped all night, and stopped with a THUD that woke me more than once.

<userid>None<//userid><name>watchking< /name><Date>1438300800000< /Date><rating>None< /rating>< Review>
I checked the availability for the suites and there were a lot available but when I was checking in the clerk said no Platinum member upgrade was available. I explained there were several suites showing up on the Starwood site. He said those are paying rooms, the suites are thousands of dollars a night. Like I have never stayed at such a room. I felt like my Platinum status was worth nothing here. I was very disappointed and felt belittled by the clerk. Then he said that we were getting a great Grand Deluxe room which was an upgrade, but when I got to the room it was just the regular room that I had booked. I called guest services and again the operator said that we do not upgrade to suites because we are a Luxury Hotel Collection. Why have the rooms sit there without being occupied, makes no sense and that is was Platinum membership is for.

When we got to the room the bathroom floor had hair on it and the sink also had dirt, my wife noticed it. Otherwise the room was nice. We liked the hallways very old looking along with the door knobs.
I used the valet for parking but when I came back to the hotel at around 2AM there were no attendants outside, no valet. My wife went to the front desk and the clerk didn't know where the valet was so we had to park our car and leave the keys with the clerk. A luxury hotel should have someone up front at all times even late at night.<//Review>

<Rate>None< /Rate><Review>We made our reservation based on the recommendation of friends, who are frequent guests at the hotel, and the room description and photos on the website. From there it went downhill.

Although the website and out confirmation indicated health club/pool, we were told at checkin that there was no available health club. We booked a Superior Room at 300 sq. ft., but the room did not resemble the photo or description on the website. There was only one night stand, rather than the two in the photo as the room was not large enough to accommodate two. There was no comfortable chair with ottoman, as in the website photo, as there clearly was no room for that either. The desk chair had a chunk of the padding missing. Not attractive.

When we called the front desk to check out, I indicated that if the total amount was the same as the electronic version of the folio sent to me that morning, I was fine with the bill. However, later in the day I received another electronic folio which had increased the total since my conversation with the front desk, by adding another day of parking. Thus charging me for three days of parking @$59/day for a two day stay at the hotel.

Needless to say, I was very disappointed with my stay at the Palace Hotel. The one bright spot was that, with one exception, the staff was very friendly.<//Review>< pictures>
None< /pictures>

<response>None<//response><review>I don't write reviews on hotel stays, but this one is really bad that I had to vent.

We had dinner in the city and decided to stay at this hotel instead of taking BART home in the evening so we could have a restful evening. We were given a 2nd floor room (normally, we get upgraded to higher floor being GOLD members). We got to our room and had an early night just to be waken up by LOUD music (it looks like our room was on top of the venue) . Upon our phone call to front desk, we were informed that the event was finishing and music should be stopping any moment. 30 minutes after, the music was still there, and still loud, we couldn't sleep (except for our young children who had fallen asleep earlier). We called again and this time we were told the music is on until midnight. We were offered to transfer to a higher floor and we agreed. We had to pack our stuff, wake up the children and transfer. It wasn't a restful evening after all. The hotel should have a guideline on the level of sound the event should have. The music (live band in this case) was way too loud!

Upon getting home today, we received the final bill by email. Instead of using our points (12,000 points), we were billed in USD. Called them, and admitted they made a mistake.

I don't think we will go back to The Palace.<//review></record>

<UserId.>None<//UserId.>< username>
GoodServiceExpected</username>
< Date>
1347667200000< /Date>
<Rate>None</Rate>< Review>
My wife booked this hotel because we generally like older hotels, but the Palace is an older hotel that has not retained the benefits of thick walls and custom craftsmanship. Instead, you can hear every neighbor, and the hotel is so thinly staffed with rude, snooty, outright pretentious personnel (except for the cleaning crew which were courteous and very friendly) that it's downright offensive to pay to stay in this hotel to be treated like filth. The reception desk staff and concierge should all be fired at this location - or sent to charm school. Perhaps San Francisco Palace Hotel staff are so high on their greatness that they don't give a damn about service, but with a number of far better, much friendlier hotels within just a few blocks of this hotel, I highly recommend that potential guests choose the other hotels over this one and have a drink in the Pied Piper (at most) but don't wast your money on the rooms at the Palace (and certainly not the service). Even the response to my review on TripAdvisor was snotty - completely dismissive of my concerns about the staff at this hotel... as if they didn't bother reading the review before responding. Like is said on TripAdivsor - from the moment you enter this hotel right through checkout you feel like this hotel is being managed on the cheap. Chintzy for a "Luxury Hotel".<//Review>

<Text>Haven't stayed at the Palace for 10+ years, but it's as I remember it...dirty with poor service. My room had dirty carpets from the entry into the room with hair and trash on the bathroom floor. There was no coffee/tea maker in the room (hotel said it's only available in suites), so, I requested hot water or an electric kettyla and the person on the phone made it sound like it was such a task that I did so. After 35 minutes, i called again to ask for the a water kettle. Only after my second call, did room service show up with a Keurig coffee maker which doesn't make tea, so I asked for a teak kettle. While I was waiting for the kettle, I happended to read the framed news clipping hanging on the wall next to the front door and was suprised that it contained disparaging remarks about Japanese and Japan which is ironic given the property is owned by a Japanese company.

Overall, the room cleanliness, amenities, and service experience was terrible, not to mention the cultural insensitivity of the furnishings.

Definitely the poorest run "upscale" hotel in San Francisco.< /Text>< date>
1377129600000</date>

<gmapID>0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb</gmapID></record></dataset><record>
<Rate>4</Rate>< gmapID>
0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb< /gmapID>
< pictures>
None</pictures>
< Text>
This is not the hotel built by William Chapman Ralston back in the year of 1875. The Palace Hotel was destroyed by fire in the 1906 earthquake. The New Palace Hotel as it was called opened in 1909.
Ralston did save his banking empire from ruin in the 1860's National depression with a cleverly devised scheme, but unfortunately he lost everything including his life in 1875, two months before the Palace Hotel opened. It was Ralston's business partner U. S. Senator William Sharon who had helped cause the collapse of Ralston's Bank when he dumped his stock in the Comstock Lode. Sharon ended up in control of the hotel as well as both the Bank and Ralston's debts, both of which he paid off at just pennies on the dollar.</Text>

<user>None< /user><Name>Jetsetter01<//Name><date>1342310400000</date><Rate>None< /Rate>< text>
I had some pleasant and unpleasant moments here. During breakfast I asked waiter why poached eggs has hard yolk. He offered me to bring new portion of poached eggs. I agreed. He brought it when I did finish my dessert. And inew eggs was again hard boiled. I refuse from it, but found in my bill $20 extra charge for that "eggs order". What a shame. But this problem was quickly resolved by very nice and professional manager. When waiter did see that I talk to manager - he promptly brought back eggs I refused and put it on my table like I accepted it. Shame again.
Porter told us that there is beautiful swimming pool at 4th floor. Kids were excited and we went there first thing, but pool is far below average. Shower in men locker room does not have shower head. Towels are old and lost it whitemess ages ago. Sad impression from pool visit we had.
Valet is crazy expensive and does not deliver in timely manner. I started to call at 8:40 to ask my car be ready at 9. Phone was busy, and at 8:45 I called front desk. They promised me to request my car and took my ticket number. And they didn't perform this. I received my car at 9:25 and I was late for my appointment. Not cool.
But most of staff is professional, friendly and goid-looking.
I received no upgrade and stayed in room with no view (most room has no view as I can see from plan).
But hotel's ground floor interiors are fabulous and very impressive.</text>

<rate>5</rate><Name>Dustin Berry< /Name><GmapID>0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb< /GmapID><Pictures>None< /Pictures>< user>

< user_id>
105529300056545653455< /user_id>
<username>royalsamurai1<//username><Time>1490987463608</Time>< Rating>
4< /Rating>
< text>
The room rates for this hotel were quite reasonable ("I thought") especially for its opulent antiquity and all its magnificence. ¬†However, with that being said, this is "definitely" not a place to stay if you're looking for an inexpensive place to lay your head down!

One of the big shortcomings that I found at this magnificent hotel was the "parking," which there wasn't any along the street and even if you could find one, I personally wouldn't park my new vehicle because of the surrounding neighborhood.

The hotel charges a fee of $59.00 for overnight parking which I find preposterous but I guess it's better than the alternative of seeing your vehicle on blocks and your wheels missing! ¬†"Ya, I know, I'm being paranoid, but I know things that only cops know!"

My first impression of this place from the outside is that it's extravagant looking. ¬†Walking inside of this place makes you feel like your stepping back into time! ¬†The interior looks like a set out of a movie scene with its old style design and elegance.

The lobby is amazing in its old style d√©cor and you feel like you're reliving the early 1900's! ¬†Too bad the prices don't reflect that era!

With our discounts you can stay in one of their "Superior Rooms," which is their basic elegant room with stylish old time furniture's.

A walking tour of the inside of this hotel is really an experience breathtaking to see, especially in the old dining room.

The Palace Hotel pool looked old fashioned and with the enclosed clear ceiling roof, kept out the notorious San Francisco sea chill that it's famous for.

The Garden Court Restaurant, which was designed in the early 1990's, is very elegant but to me the prices were expensive but then again, I guess it goes into the upkeep of the place!

With our family being "everything computer related" the hotel charges a $15.00 fee for WIFI!

Some notable events at the hotel:

In 1891, the monarch of the Kingdom of Hawaii at the time, King Kalakaua, died on January 20, 1891.

In 1919, former president, Woodrow Wilson gave speeches in the Garden Court in support of the Treaty of Versailles and the League of Nations.

In 1923, Warren G. Harding's term as President ended suddenly when he died at the Palace Hotel, in Room 8064, an eighth floor suite that overlooks Market Street.

In 1945, the Palace Hotel hosted a banquet to mark the opening session of the United Nations.

In 1954, the hotel was sold to Sheraton Hotels and became the Sheraton-Palace Hotel.

In 1959, Soviet Premier Nikita Khrushchev spoke at a banquet at the Sheraton-Palace during his American tour.

In 1969, the Garden Court was declared a San Francisco Landmark.

In 1973, the hotel was bought by the Japanese Kyo-Ya group, along with all of their hotels in the Hawaiian Islands. ¬†Sheraton continued to manage the hotel and the name stayed the same.

In 1984, the entire structure of the Sheraton-Palace was declared a landmark.

From January 1989 to April 1991, the Sheraton-Palace Hotel undergoes a $150 million restoration that garnered national media attention and numerous awards.

In 1990's the hotel dropped the Sheraton name and transferred to another division of Starwood Hotels, The Luxury Collection, becoming, again, the Palace Hotel.

In 1997, the finale of the David Fincher film The Game, starring Michael Douglas, was shot in the Garden Court.

In 2013, the famous Maxfield Parrish painting which still hangs in the equally famous Pied Piper Bar was removed and scheduled to be auctioned off at Christie's but strong public opposition to its removal, however, the hotel's owners relented and instead had the painting cleaned, restored, and returned to the bar where it was rehung with considerable fanfare on August 22, 2013.

Over the years, the Palace Hotel has had many guests from such notables as former presidents, George Bush, Woodrow Wilson, and Soviet Premier Nikita Khrushchev, to football greats like Joe Montana and Singer Donna Summer to name just a few!

Overall, our stay here was memorable!</text>

3<//Rating>
<text>Pulled up to the hotel and saw a sign for palace parking, we pulled into the lot and two guys watching tv in a booth looked up at us and kept watching their show, my husband walked over and said we needed to park. We grab our bags and crossed a very busy intersection with no cross walks and came inside.

We walked up to the front desk and wait for someone to help us, finally two men came out of the office and helped us.

We paid 230 for an extremely basic room facing another Window.

Ordering room service- we were not impressed with the food, the bar down stairs was extremely muggy and smelly.

Finally when checking out it took so long to get our car back from the garage, we waited around for awhile.

When driving away we realized they charged us 60$ for one night of parking. I thought this could be a mistake so I called and asked to talk to someone. The woman on the phone informed us that parking was in fact 68.28/per night, I was shocked! I asked why we were never informed and she said valets only tells you if you ask. I asked why in the world they would charge people that price and never tell them? She asked if I would walk into a store and purchase things without asking the prices... Wait WHAT?! The worst customer service I've ever experienced.

The cherry on top was the 200$ deposit that took from our account without telling us!!!

Added two stars: finally talked to KC the manager and he refunded the parking and apologized for the customer service. Thank you for your help!<//text><pics>None<//pics><Response>None</Response><gmapID>0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb< /gmapID></record>

The first time it occurred I accepted the response from the front desk that I need to keep it away from phones, etc. However the 2nd, 3rd, 4th, etc. time when I kept the key completely away from my phone and the key card still didn't work it was very frustrating.</review>

< review>
Was really looking forward to spending the weekend at the Palace Hotel, but ended up being sorely disappointed..the breakdown:

Pros:
- Location
- Beds (I could sleep all day!)
- Shower

Cons:
- HOTEL STAFF / CUSTOMER SERVICE: Gosh, as a Gold member and previous Platinum member who has traveled extensively for work (Monday - Thursday) and for pleasure (28 countries) the Palace definitely takes the cake for rudest, most uppity front desk customer service. While the hotel itself is beautiful, I would not recommend this to anyone who will need services beyond check-in.
- ROOM SERVICE: The food was awful. Such a waste of $50. Overpriced and did not live up to a Luxury Collection standard.
- ATTITUDE: The Palace will nickel and dime you for anything and everything.</review>

< review>
We were checked in with two separate confirmations due to a free night using points. The gentleman behind the desk told us he was able to keep us in the same room for the 3 nights, and we appreciated it. That night at 3am we were awakened by someone trying to open the door. I finally got out of bed to tell them the room was occupied. At this time I called the front desk and let them know what happened. Fifteen minutes later there was knocking at the door-it was hotel personnel. At 6am there was someone else knocking at the door, but we did not get up. The next morning we talked to the manager on duty, and she apologized for the inconvenience. She explained it was a computer error. No problem, things like that happen. When we returned to our room later, our room had not been serviced. We were told we would have water and breakfast vouchers waiting, and we received neither. The next morning my husband spoke to another manager who gave him our vouchers and when we returned to the room it was not serviced, but there was water for us. We were most disappointed, especially since it was an expensive stay for us.</review>

< text>
My initail assigned room which I prepaid was in poor shape. Cracked bathroom sink, ripped carpeting, and furnitire all chipped and scuffed. I was moved to an upgraded room, but it was only larger but conditions were the same.
In addition, there was a huge conference that spilled into the lobby and restaurants and bars that made the street floor extremely chaotic. If I was told of the conference i would have selected another SPG hotel.</text>

< Text>
This is supposed to be a 5-star hotel and part of the ‚ÄúLuxury Collection‚Äù There was no luxury to be found here.

1. When I checked in the front desk person tried to charge me $80 more per night ‚Äì he ended up trying to check in another person with another rate
2. Took 20 minutes to check-in
3. Was not upgraded on night 1 and stayed in a room that was only 300 square feet
4. Packed my bags again in the morning and dropped off at bell stand and was treated very rudely ‚Äì person told me to bring my bag to him in front of the stand vs. him walking over to me at the front desk and getting it from me.
5. Night 2 ‚Äì Went to get my keys and again they had the wrong room rate -- $xxx vs. $xxx and again I had to find the hotel manager this morning to have the bill adjusted.
6. Last night, I took the advice of the concierge and went to the sushi restaurant at the hotel ‚Äì this was a nightmare. I have copied in the manager of the restaurant on this email.
a. Took me 10 min. to get my order taken
b. Took over 25 min. for my sushi to be delivered.
c. Was told the restaurant was understaffed.<//Text>

From the moment we checked in there were issues. The lady at the front desk didn't even want to explain to us where the facilities were, where breakfast was etc. We then were charged an authorization check on our card (which is routine), but usually we are told this before it happens. Instead, I get charged without any communication from the lady at the front desk. Then, we get upstairs and notice that the mini bar is totally empty, which is strange. Not only that, the few lights in the room weren't working. We didn't want to make this into a huge deal so we headed out for dinner and came back. At night, the fire alarms go off for 10-15 minutes without any warning. I was scared and alarmed as it was 1:30am. Then, again the fire alarms go off at 9:00am, but this time at least there was a reason. So we couldn't sleep in more and we couldn't even take a nap in the morning. In the morning, we did not even get a final receipt slipped under our door, again a routine practice. Long story short, would not recommend this place.</text>< Pics>

<gmap_id>0x808580881f0c9dd7:0xbe09e1083f7d7fcb<//gmap_id><user>109177322366829855601< /user><resp>None< /resp><user_name>Lawyers OnTour< /user_name>< text>
(Translated by Google) A beautiful old fashioned hotel, once one of the largest in the world. Feel the spirit of the old days, when you stroll through the wide, richly decorated corridors, you sip a drink in the bar, or you eat lunch in a restaurant under a glass dome ... Beautiful.

Rooms in the hotel are a mistake. They have the Novotel standard for a much higher price, they are small and tight for five stars. It is outrageous that the hotel describes rooms as having a seating area, which in practice turns out to be a small bench in front of the bed. Tragedy. In the room there is no kettle, no coffee or even a bar. Very slow service at check-in. five-hour hotel awaits over half an hour! The swimming pool in the object is a small, not worth the sunset changing into swimsuits. If it were not for the history connected with the object and the fabulous common parts, it does not make sense to spend the night here. Begin the drink at the bar and calmly see everything. Hotel parking twice as expensive than any other in the area.

This is a very good hotel with a good location in San Fransisco. You get what you pay for. I liked the bed and the pillow. The bathroom was also good. Although we did not watch much tv I appreciated the big tv screen. We did not have breakfast at the hotel and unfortunately we did not test the hotels interesting cocktail list. I liked the staff.My only complain is about the wifi. In 2017 you should not pay for having access to wifi in your hotel room, not even at a luxury hotel. In the lobby it is for free.<//Text>
